[My]0-i heart was beating heavily , and [I]0-i felt choked . [I]0-i did not want to look but [I]0-i must . " But [he]840-the doctor was [a jolly decent fellow]4325-a jolly decent fellow generous , open - handed . " However [we]865-we shall miss [him]840-the doctor sha n't [we]865-we , [Mrs. May]114-meg ? "[840-the doctor] [he]840-the doctor bawled suddenly , startling [us]865-we , making [us]865-we glance at the bed .

[He]840-the doctor lit [his]840-the doctor pipe and puffed voluminously in order to obscure the attraction of [his]840-the doctor glass . Meanwhile [we]865-we examined the papers . There were very few letters one or two addressed to [Paris]169-paris . There were many bills , and receipts , and notes business , all business .

There was hardly a trace of sentiment among [all the litter]866-all the litter . [[My]0-i mother]515-my mother sorted out such papers as [she]515-my mother considered valuable ; the others , letters and missives which [she]515-my mother glanced at cursorily and put aside , [she]515-my mother took into [the kitchen]451-the kitchen and burned . [She]515-my mother seemed afraid to find out too much .

[The doctor]840-the doctor continued to colour [his]840-the doctor tobacco smoke with a few pensive words .

" Ay , "[840-the doctor] [he]840-the doctor said , " there are two ways . [You]0-i can burn [your]0-i lamp with a big draught , and it 'll flare away , till the oil 's gone , then it 'll stink and smoke itself out . Or [you]0-i can keep it trim on the kitchen table , dirty [your]0-i fingers occasionally trimming it up , and it 'll last a long time , and sink out mildly . "[840-the doctor] Here [he]840-the doctor turned to [his]840-the doctor glass , and finding it empty , was awakened to reality .

" Anything [I]840-the doctor can do , [Madam]4327-madam ? "[840-the doctor] [he]840-the doctor asked .

" No , thank [you]4327-madam . "[840-the doctor]

" Ay , [I]840-the doctor do n't suppose there 's much to settle . [He]558-a fellow 'd had [his]558-a fellow fling in [his]558-a fellow day , though , [ma'am]4312-ma'am . [Ay]170-ay must ha ' had some rich times . No lasting satisfaction in it though always wanting , craving . There 's nothing like marrying [you]0-i 've got [your]0-i dish before [you]0-i then , and [you]0-i 've got to eat it . "[840-the doctor] [He]840-the doctor lapsed again into reflection , from which [he]840-the doctor did not rouse till [we]870-we had locked up the desk , burned the useless papers , put the others into [my]0-i pockets and the black bag , and were standing ready to depart . Then [the doctor]840-the doctor looked up suddenly and said :

" But what about the funeral ? "[840-the doctor]

Then [he]840-the doctor noticed the weariness of [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother 's look , and [he]840-the doctor jumped up , and quickly seized [his]840-the doctor hat , saying :

" Come across to [[my]840-the doctor wife]4331-my wife and have a cup of tea . Buried in these dam holes [a fellow]558-a fellow gets such a boor . Do come [[my]840-the doctor little wife]4333-my little wife is lonely come just to see [her]4333-my little wife . "[840-the doctor]

[[My]0-i mother]515-my mother smiled and thanked [him]840-the doctor . [We]870-we turned to go . [[My]0-i mother]515-my mother hesitated in [her]515-my mother walk ; on the threshold of [the room]518-the room [she]515-my mother glanced round at the bed , but [she]515-my mother went on .

Outside , in the fresh air of the fading afternoon , [I]0-i could not believe it was true . It was not true , that sad , colourless face with grey beard , wavering in the yellow candle - light . It was a lie , that wooden bedstead , [that deaf woman]876-that deaf woman , they were fading phrases of the untruth . That yellow blaze of little sunflowers was true , and the shadow from the sun - dial on [the warm old almshouses]877-the warm old almshouses that was real . The heavy afternoon sunlight came round [us]870-we warm and reviving ; [we]870-we shivered , and the untruth went out of [our]870-we veins , and [we]870-we were no longer chilled .

[[The doctor]840-the doctor 's house]879-the doctor 's house stood sweetly among the beech trees , and at the iron fence in front of [the little lawn]880-the little lawn [a woman]881-a woman was talking to a beautiful Jersey cow that pushed its dark nose through the fence from [the field beyond]882-the field beyond . [She]881-a woman was [a little , dark woman with vivid colouring]883-a little , dark woman with vivid colouring ; [she]881-a woman rubbed the nose of the delicate animal , peeped right into the dark eyes , and talked in a lovable Scottish speech ; talked as [a mother]884-a mother talks softly to [[her]884-a mother child]885-her child .

When [she]881-a woman turned round in surprise to greet [us]870-we there was still the softness of a rich affection in [her]881-a woman eyes . [She]881-a woman gave [us]870-we tea , and scones , and apply jelly , and all the time [we]870-we listened with delight to [her]881-a woman voice , which was musical as bees humming in the lime trees . Though [she]881-a woman said nothing significant [we]870-we listened to [her]881-a woman attentively .

[[Her]881-a woman husband]677-her husband was merry and kind . [She]881-a woman glanced at [him]677-her husband with quick glances of apprehension , and [her]881-a woman eyes avoided [him]677-her husband . [He]677-her husband , in [his]677-her husband merry , frank way , chaffed [her]881-a woman , and praised [her]881-a woman extravagantly , and teased [her]881-a woman again . Then [he]677-her husband became a trifle uneasy . [I]0-i think [she]881-a woman was afraid [he]677-her husband had been drinking ; [I]0-i think [she]881-a woman was shaken with horror when [she]881-a woman found [him]677-her husband tipsy , and bewildered and terrified when [she]881-a woman saw [him]677-her husband drunk . [They]887-they had [no children]888-no children . [I]0-i noticed [he]677-her husband ceased to joke when [she]881-a woman became a little constrained . [He]677-her husband glanced at [her]881-a woman often , and looked somewhat pitiful when [she]881-a woman avoided [his]677-her husband looks , and [he]677-her husband grew uneasy , and [I]0-i could see [he]677-her husband wanted to go away .

" [I]677-her husband had better go with [you]0-i to see [the vicar]4334-the vicar , then , "[677-her husband] [he]677-her husband said to [me]0-i , and [we]889-we left [the room]518-the room , whose windows looked south , over [the meadows]891-the meadows , [the room where dainty little water - colours , and beautiful bits of embroidery , and empty flower vases , and two dirty novels from [the town library]893-the town library]892-the room where dainty little water - colours , and beautiful bits of embroidery , and empty flower vases , and two dirty novels from the town library , and the closed piano , and the odd cups , and the chipped spout of the teapot causing stains on the cloth all told one story .

[We]889-we went to [the joiner]894-the joiner 's and ordered the coffin , and [the doctor]840-the doctor had a glass of whisky on it ; the graveyard fees were paid , and [the doctor]840-the doctor sealed the engagement with a drop of brandy ; [the vicar]4334-the vicar 's port completed [the doctor]840-the doctor 's joviality , and [we]889-we went [home]4184-home .

This time the disquiet in [the little woman]900-the little woman 's dark eyes could not dispel [the doctor]840-the doctor 's merriment . [He]677-her husband rattled away , and [she]900-the little woman nervously twisted [her]900-the little woman wedding ring . [He]677-her husband insisted on driving [us]889-we to [the station]555-the station , in spite of [our]889-we alarm .

" But [you]0-i will be quite safe with [him]677-her husband , "[468-his wife] said [[his]677-her husband wife]468-his wife , in [her]468-his wife caressing Highland speech . When [she]900-the little woman shook hands at parting [I]0-i noticed the hardness of the little palm ; and [I]0-i have always hated an old , black alpaca dress .

It is such a long way home from [the station at [Eberwich]6-eberwich]904-the station at eberwich . [We]889-we rode part way in [the bus]905-the bus ; then [we]889-we walked . It is a very long way for [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother , when [her]515-my mother steps are heavy with trouble .

[Rebecca]115-rebecca was out by the rhododendrons looking for [us]889-we . [She]115-rebecca hurried to [us]889-we all solicitous , and asked [mother]4146-mother if [she]115-rebecca had had tea .

" But [you]4146-mother 'll do with another cup , "[115-rebecca] [she]115-rebecca said , and ran back into [the house]563-the house .

[She]115-rebecca came into [the dining - room]511-the dining - room to take [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother 's bonnet and coat . [She]115-rebecca wanted [us]889-we to talk ; [she]115-rebecca was distressed on [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother 's behalf ; [she]115-rebecca noticed the blackness that lay under [her]115-rebecca eyes , and [she]115-rebecca fidgeted about , unwilling to ask anything , yet uneasy and anxious to know .

" [Lettie]116-lettie has been [home]4184-home , "[115-rebecca] [she]115-rebecca said .

" And gone back again ? "[4146-mother] asked [mother]4146-mother .

" [She]116-lettie only came to change [her]116-lettie dress . [She]116-lettie put the green poplin on . [She]116-lettie wondered where [you]115-rebecca 'd gone . "[115-rebecca]

" What did [you]115-rebecca tell [her]116-lettie ? "[115-rebecca]

" [I]115-rebecca said [you]115-rebecca 'd just gone out a bit . [She]116-lettie said [she]116-lettie was glad . [She]116-lettie was as lively as a squirrel . "[115-rebecca]

[Rebecca]115-rebecca looked wistfully at [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother . At length [the latter]627-the latter said :

" [He]627-the latter 's dead , [Rebecca]115-rebecca . [I]627-the latter have seen [him]627-the latter . "[627-the latter]

" Now thank [God]171-god for that no more need to worry over [him]627-the latter . "[115-rebecca]

" Well ! [He]627-the latter died all alone , [Rebecca]115-rebecca all alone . "[627-the latter]

" [He]627-the latter died as [you]115-rebecca 've lived , "[115-rebecca] said [Becky]115-rebecca with some asperity .

" But [I]627-the latter 've had [the children]4276-the children , [I]627-the latter 've had [the children [we]4338-we wo n't tell [Lettie]116-lettie]4337-the children we wo n't tell lettie , [Rebecca]115-rebecca . "[627-the latter]

" No ' m. "[115-rebecca] [Rebecca]115-rebecca left [the room]518-the room .

" [You]115-rebecca and [Lettie]116-lettie will have the money , "[4146-mother] said [mother]4146-mother to [me]0-i . There was a sum of four thousand pounds or so . It was left to [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother ; or , in default to [Lettie]116-lettie and [me]0-i .

" Well , [mother]4146-mother if it 's [ours]4338-we , it 's [yours]115-rebecca . "[4146-mother]

There was silence for some minutes , then [she]4146-mother said , " [You]115-rebecca might have had [a father]4340-a father "[4146-mother]

" [We]4338-we 're thankful [we]4338-we had n't , [mother]4146-mother . [You]4146-mother spared [us]4338-we that . "[4146-mother]

" If ever [you]115-rebecca feel scorn for one who is near [you]115-rebecca rising in [your]115-rebecca throat , try and be generous , [[my]4146-mother lad]4342-my lad . "[4146-mother]

" Well "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" Yes , "[515-my mother] [she]515-my mother replied , " [we]4338-we 'll say no more . Sometime [you]0-i must tell [Lettie]116-lettie [you]0-i tell [her]515-my mother . "[515-my mother]

" Who knows ? "[515-my mother] [she]515-my mother asked , [her]515-my mother face hardening .

" [Mother]117-mother , [Becky]115-rebecca , and [ourselves]4338-we . "[515-my mother]

" No . "[515-my mother]

" Then it 's a good thing [he]919-the man who was our father is out of the way if [he]919-the man who was our father was such a nuisance to [mother]4146-mother . Where is [she]4146-mother ? "[515-my mother]

" [Upstairs]532-upstairs . "[515-my mother]

[Lettie]116-lettie ran to [her]515-my mother .

CHAPTER V

THE SCENT OF BLOOD

The death of [the man who was [[our]920-our father]921-our father]919-the man who was our father changed [our]920-our lives . It was not that [we]920-our suffered a great grief ; the chief trouble was the unanswered crying of failure . But [we]920-our were changed in [our]920-our feelings and in [our]920-our relations ; there was a new consciousness , a new carefulness .

[We]920-our had lived between [the woods]600-the woods and [the water]429-the water all [our]920-our lives , [Lettie]116-lettie and [I]0-i , and [she]116-lettie had sought the bright notes in everything . [She]116-lettie seemed to hear the water laughing , and the leaves tittering and giggling like [young girls]924-young girls ; the aspen fluttered like the draperies of a flirt , and the sound of the wood - pigeons was almost foolish in its sentimentality .

Lately , however , [she]116-lettie had noticed again the cruel pitiful crying of a hedgehog caught in a gin , and [she]116-lettie had noticed the traps for [the fierce little murderers]925-the fierce little murderers , traps walled in with a small fence of fir , and baited with the guts of a killed rabbit .

On an afternoon a short time after [our]920-our visit to [Cossethay]10-cossethay , [Lettie]116-lettie sat in the window seat . The sun clung to [her]116-lettie hair , and kissed [her]116-lettie with passionate splashes of colour brought from the vermilion , dying creeper outside . The sun loved [Lettie]116-lettie , and was loath to leave [her]116-lettie . [She]116-lettie looked out over [Nethermere]1-nethermere to Highclose , vague in the September mist . Had it not been for the scarlet light on [her]116-lettie face , [I]0-i should have thought [her]116-lettie look was sad and serious . [She]116-lettie nestled up to the window , and leaned [her]116-lettie head against the wooden shaft . Gradually [she]116-lettie drooped into sleep . Then [she]116-lettie became wonderfully childish again it was [the girl of seventeen]926-the girl of seventeen sleeping there , with [her]116-lettie full pouting lips slightly apart , and the breath coming lightly . [I]0-i felt the old feeling of responsibility ; [I]0-i must protect [her]116-lettie , and take care of [her]116-lettie .

There was a crunch of the gravel . It was [Leslie]121-leslie coming . [He]121-leslie lifted [his]121-leslie hat to [her]116-lettie , thinking [she]116-lettie was looking . [He]121-leslie had that fine , lithe physique , suggestive of much animal vigour ; [[his]121-leslie person]927-his person was exceedingly attractive ; [one]606-one watched [him]121-leslie move about , and felt pleasure . [His]121-leslie face was less pleasing than [[his]121-leslie person]927-his person . [He]121-leslie was not handsome ; [his]121-leslie eyebrows were too light , [his]121-leslie nose was large and ugly , and [his]121-leslie forehead , though high and fair , was without dignity . But [he]121-leslie had a frank , good - natured expression , and a fine , wholesome laugh .

[He]121-leslie wondered why [she]116-lettie did not move . As [he]121-leslie came nearer [he]121-leslie saw . Then [he]121-leslie winked at [me]0-i and came in . [He]121-leslie tiptoed across [the room]518-the room to look at [her]116-lettie . The sweet carelessness of [her]116-lettie attitude , the appealing , half - pitiful girlishness of [her]116-lettie face touched [his]121-leslie responsive heart , and [he]121-leslie leaned forward and kissed [her]116-lettie cheek where already was a crimson stain of sunshine .

[She]116-lettie roused half out of [her]116-lettie sleep with a little , petulant " Oh ! "[121-leslie] as [an awakened child]931-an awakened child . [He]121-leslie sat down behind [her]116-lettie , and gently drew [her]116-lettie head against [him]121-leslie , looking down at [her]116-lettie with a tender , soothing smile . [I]0-i thought [she]116-lettie was going to fall asleep thus . But [her]116-lettie eyelids quivered , and [her]116-lettie eyes beneath them flickered into consciousness .

" [Leslie]121-leslie ! oh ! Let [me]116-lettie go ! "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie exclaimed , pushing [him]121-leslie away . [He]121-leslie loosed [her]116-lettie , and rose , looking at [her]116-lettie reproachfully . [She]116-lettie shook [her]116-lettie dress , and went quickly to the mirror to arrange [her]116-lettie hair .

" [You]121-leslie are mean ! "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie exclaimed , looking very flushed , vexed , and dishevelled .

[He]121-leslie laughed indulgently , saying , " [You]116-lettie should n't go to sleep then and look so pretty . Who could help ? "[121-leslie]

" It is not nice ! "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said , frowning with irritation .

" [We]4346-we are not ' nice ' are [we]4346-we ? [I]117-mother thought [we]4346-we were proud of [our]4346-we unconventionality . Why should n't [I]117-mother kiss [you]116-lettie ? "[117-mother]

" Because it is a question of [me]117-mother , not of [you]116-lettie alone . "[117-mother]

" [Dear]4347-dear [me]117-mother , [you]121-leslie are in a way ! "[117-mother]

" [Mother]117-mother is coming . "[117-mother]

" Is [she]117-mother ? [You]121-leslie had better tell [her]117-mother . "[117-mother]

[Mother]117-mother was very fond of [Leslie]121-leslie .

" Well , [sir]4348-sir , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said , " why are [you]121-leslie frowning ? "[116-lettie]

[He]121-leslie broke into a laugh .

" [Lettie]116-lettie is scolding [me]515-my mother for kissing [her]116-lettie when [she]116-lettie was playing ' [Sleeping Beauty]172-sleeping beauty . ' "[515-my mother]

" [The conceit of [the boy]798-the boy]4349-the conceit of the boy , to play [Prince]173-prince ! "[515-my mother] said [[my]0-i mother]515-my mother .

" Oh , but it appears [I]121-leslie was sadly out of character , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said ruefully .

[Lettie]116-lettie laughed and forgave [him]121-leslie .

" Well , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said , looking at [her]116-lettie and smiling , " [I]121-leslie came to ask [you]116-lettie to go out . "[121-leslie]

" It is a lovely afternoon , "[4146-mother] said [mother]4146-mother .

[She]4146-mother glanced at [him]121-leslie , and said :

" [I]4146-mother feel dreadfully lazy . "[4146-mother]

" Never mind ! "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie replied , " [you]116-lettie 'll wake up . Go and put [your]116-lettie hat on . "[121-leslie]

[He]121-leslie sounded impatient . [She]4146-mother looked at [him]121-leslie .

[He]121-leslie seemed to be smiling peculiarly .

[She]4146-mother lowered [her]4146-mother eyes and went out of [the room]518-the room .

" [She]4146-mother 'll come all right , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said to [himself]121-leslie , and to [me]0-i . " [She]4146-mother likes to play [you]0-i on a string . "[121-leslie]

[She]4146-mother must have heard [him]121-leslie . When [she]4146-mother came in again , drawing on [her]4146-mother gloves , [she]4146-mother said quietly :

" [You]121-leslie come as well , [Pat]129-pat . "[4146-mother]

[He]121-leslie swung round and stared at [her]4146-mother in angry amazement .

" [I]0-i had rather stay and finish this sketch , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , feeling uncomfortable .

" No , but do come , there 's [a dear]4351-a dear . "[4146-mother] [She]4146-mother took the brush from [my]0-i hand , and drew [me]0-i from [my]0-i chair . The blood flushed into [his]121-leslie cheeks . [He]121-leslie went quietly into [the hall]703-the hall and brought [my]0-i cap .

" All right ! "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said angrily . " [Women]561-women like to fancy [themselves]561-women [Napoleons]174-napoleons . "[121-leslie]

" [They]561-women do , [dear Iron Duke]175-dear iron duke , [they]561-women do , "[4146-mother] [she]4146-mother mocked .

" Yet , there 's [a Waterloo]4353-a waterloo in all [their]561-women histories , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said , since [she]4146-mother had supplied [him]121-leslie with the idea .

" Say [Peterloo]176-peterloo , [[my]4146-mother general]4354-my general , say [Peterloo]176-peterloo . "[4146-mother]

" Ay , [Peterloo]176-peterloo , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie replied , with a splendid curl of the lip " Easy conquests ! "[121-leslie]

" ' [He]121-leslie came , [he]121-leslie saw , [he]121-leslie conquered , ' "[116-lettie] [Lettie]116-lettie recited .

" Are [you]116-lettie coming ? "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said , getting more angry .

" When [you]121-leslie bid [me]4146-mother , "[4146-mother] [she]4146-mother replied , taking [my]0-i arm .

[We]936-we went through [the wood]504-the wood , and through [the dishevelled border - land]938-the dishevelled border - land to [the high road]939-the high road , through [the border - land that should have been park - like , but which was shaggy with loose grass and yellow mole - hills , ragged with gorse and bramble and briar , with wandering old thorn - trees , and a queer clump of Scotch firs]940-the border - land that should have been park - like , but which was shaggy with loose grass and yellow mole - hills , ragged with gorse and bramble and briar , with wandering old thorn - trees , and a queer clump of scotch firs .

On [the highway]941-the highway the leaves were falling , and they chattered under [our]936-we steps . [The water]429-the water was mild and blue , and the corn stood drowsily in ' stook . "[936-we]

[We]936-we climbed [the hill behind Highclose]943-the hill behind highclose , and walked on along [the upland]944-the upland , looking across towards [the hills of [arid Derbyshire]37-derbyshire]945-the hills of arid derbyshire , and seeing [them]945-the hills of arid derbyshire not , because it was autumn . [We]936-we came in sight of the head - stocks of [the pit at [Selsby]13-selsby]946-the pit at selsby , and of [the ugly village]947-the ugly village standing blank and naked on [the brow of [the hill]502-the hill]948-the brow of the hill .

[Lettie]116-lettie was in very high spirits . [She]116-lettie laughed and joked continually . [She]116-lettie picked bunches of hips and stuck them in [her]116-lettie dress . Having got a thorn in [her]116-lettie finger from a spray of blackberries , [she]116-lettie went to [Leslie]121-leslie to have it squeezed out . [We]936-we were all quite gay as [we]936-we turned off [the high road]939-the high road and went along [the bridle path]951-the bridle path , with [the woods]600-the woods on [our]936-we right , [the high Strelley hills]953-the high strelley hills shutting in [[our]936-we small valley]954-our small valley in front , and [the fields]955-the fields and [the common]956-the common to the left . About half way down [the lane]499-the lane [we]936-we heard the slurr of the scythestone on the scythe . [Lettie]116-lettie went to the hedge to see . It was [George]108-george mowing the oats on the steep hillside where the machine could not go . [[His]108-george father]630-his father was tying up the corn into sheaves .

Straightening [his]630-his father back , [Mr. Saxton]130-mr. saxton saw [us]936-we , and called to [us]936-we to come and help . [We]936-we pushed through a gap in the hedge and went up to [him]630-his father .

" Now then , "[465-the father] said [the father]465-the father to [me]0-i , " take that coat off , "[465-the father] and to [Lettie]116-lettie : " Have [you]116-lettie brought [us]936-we a drink ? No ; come , that sounds bad ! Going a walk [I]630-his father guess . [You]116-lettie see what it is to get fat , "[630-his father] and [he]630-his father pulled a wry face as [he]630-his father bent over to tie the corn . [He]630-his father was [a man beautifully ruddy and burly , in the prime of life]960-a man beautifully ruddy and burly , in the prime of life .

" Show [me]116-lettie , [I]116-lettie 'll do some , "[116-lettie] said [Lettie]116-lettie .

" Nay , "[630-his father] [he]630-his father answered gently , " it would scratch [your]116-lettie wrists and break [your]116-lettie stays . Hark at [my]630-his father hands "[630-his father] [he]630-his father rubbed them together " like sandpaper ! "[630-his father]

[George]108-george had [his]108-george back to [us]961-us , and had not noticed [us]961-us . [He]108-george continued to mow . [Leslie]121-leslie watched [him]108-george .

" That 's a fine movement ! "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie exclaimed .

" Yes , "[465-the father] replied [the father]465-the father , rising very red in the face from the tying , " and [[our]961-us [George]108-george]4148-our george enjoys a bit o ' mowing . It puts [you]4356-you in fine condition when [you]4356-you get over the first stiffness . "[465-the father]

[We]961-us moved across to the standing corn . The sun being mild , [George]108-george had thrown off [his]108-george hat , and [his]108-george black hair was moist and twisted into confused half - curls . Firmly planted , [he]108-george swung with a beautiful rhythm from the waist . On the hip of [his]108-george belted breeches hung the scythestone ; [his]108-george shirt , faded almost white , was torn just above the belt , and showed the muscles of [his]108-george back playing like lights upon the white sand of [a brook]963-a brook . There was something exceedingly attractive in the rhythmic body .

[I]0-i spoke to [him]108-george , and [he]108-george turned round . [He]108-george looked straight at [Lettie]116-lettie with a flashing , betraying smile . [He]108-george was remarkably handsome . [He]108-george tried to say some words of greeting , then [he]108-george bent down and gathered an armful of corn , and deliberately bound it up .

Like [him]108-george , [Lettie]116-lettie had found nothing to say . [Leslie]121-leslie , however , remarked :

" [I]121-leslie should think mowing is a nice exercise . "[121-leslie]

" It is , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie replied , and continued , as [Leslie]121-leslie picked up the scythe , " but it will make [you]121-leslie sweat , and [your]121-leslie hands will be sore . "[121-leslie]

[Leslie]121-leslie tossed [his]121-leslie head a little , threw off [his]121-leslie coat , and said briefly :

" How do [you]121-leslie do it ? "[121-leslie] Without waiting for a reply [he]121-leslie proceeded . [George]108-george said nothing , but turned to [Lettie]116-lettie .

" [You]108-george are picturesque , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said , a trifle awkwardly , " Quite fit for an Idyll . "[116-lettie]

" And [you]116-lettie ? "[108-george] [he]108-george said .

[She]116-lettie shrugged [her]116-lettie shoulders , laughed , and turned to pick up a scarlet pimpernel .

" How do [you]108-george bind the corn ? "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie asked .

[He]108-george took some long straws , cleaned them , and showed [her]116-lettie the way to hold them . Instead of attending , [she]116-lettie looked at [his]108-george hands , big , hard , inflamed by the snaith of the scythe .

" [I]116-lettie do n't think [I]116-lettie could do it , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said .

" No , "[108-george] [he]108-george replied quietly , and watched [Leslie]121-leslie mowing . [The latter who was wonderfully ready at everything]964-the latter who was wonderfully ready at everything , was doing fairly well , but [he]964-the latter who was wonderfully ready at everything had not the invincible sweep of [the other]689-the other , nor did [he]964-the latter who was wonderfully ready at everything make the same crisp crunching music .

" [I]108-george bet [he]108-george 'll sweat , "[108-george] said [George]108-george .

" Do n't [you]108-george ? "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie replied .

" A bit but [I]964-the latter who was wonderfully ready at everything 'm not dressed up . "[964-the latter who was wonderfully ready at everything]

" Do [you]108-george know , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said suddenly , " [your]108-george arms tempt [me]116-lettie to touch them . They are such a fine brown colour , and they look so hard . "[116-lettie]

[He]108-george held out one arm to [her]116-lettie . [She]116-lettie hesitated , then [she]116-lettie swiftly put [her]116-lettie finger tips on the smooth brown muscle , and drew them along . Quickly [she]116-lettie hid [her]116-lettie hand into the folds of [her]116-lettie skirt , blushing .

[He]108-george laughed a low , quiet laugh , at once pleasant and startling to hear .

" [I]116-lettie wish [I]116-lettie could work here , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said , looking away at the standing corn , and [the dim blue woods]966-the dim blue woods . [He]108-george followed [her]116-lettie look , and laughed quietly , with indulgent resignation .

" [I]116-lettie do ! "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said emphatically .

" [You]116-lettie feel so fine , "[108-george] [he]108-george said , pushing [his]108-george hand through [his]108-george open shirt front , and gently rubbing the muscles of [his]108-george side . " It 's a pleasure to work or to stand still . It 's a pleasure to [yourself]116-lettie [your]116-lettie own physique . "[108-george]

[She]116-lettie looked at [him]108-george , full at [his]108-george physical beauty , as if [he]108-george were some great firm bud of life .

[Leslie]121-leslie came up , wiping [his]108-george brow .

" [Jove]177-jove , "[108-george] said [he]108-george , " [I]108-george do perspire . "[108-george]

[George]108-george picked up [his]108-george coat and helped [him]108-george into it ; saying :

" [You]108-george may take a chill . "[108-george]

" It 's a jolly nice form of exercise , "[108-george] said [he]108-george .

[George]108-george , who had been feeling one finger tip , now took out [his]108-george pen - knife and proceeded to dig a thorn from [his]108-george hand .

" What a hide [you]108-george must have , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie .

[Lettie]116-lettie said nothing , but [she]116-lettie recoiled slightly .

[The father]465-the father , glad of an excuse to straighten [his]465-the father back and to chat , came to [us]968-we .

" [You]121-leslie 'd soon had enough , "[465-the father] [he]465-the father said , laughing to [Leslie]121-leslie .

[George]108-george startled [us]968-we with a sudden , " Holloa . "[108-george] [We]968-we turned , and saw a rabbit , which had burst from the corn , go coursing through the hedge , dodging and bounding the sheaves . The standing corn was a patch along [the hill - side]969-the hill - side some fifty paces in length , and ten or so in width .

" [I]465-the father did n't think there 'd have been any in , "[465-the father] said [the father]465-the father , picking up a short rake , and going to the low wall of the corn . [We]968-we all followed .

" Watch ! "[465-the father] said [the father]465-the father , " if [you]121-leslie see the heads of the corn shake ! "[465-the father]

[We]968-we prowled round [the patch of corn]972-the patch of corn .

" Hold ! Look out ! "[465-the father] shouted [the father]465-the father excitedly , and immediately after a rabbit broke from the cover .

" [Ay Ay Ay]170-ay , "[465-the father] was the shout , " turn [him]975-the little wretch turn [him]975-the little wretch ! "[465-the father] [We]968-we set off full pelt . The bewildered little brute , scared by [Leslie]121-leslie 's wild running and crying , turned from its course , and dodged across [the hill]502-the hill , threading its terrified course through the maze of lying sheaves , spurting on in a painful zigzag , now bounding over an untied bundle of corn , now swerving from the sound of a shout . [The little wretch]975-the little wretch was hard pressed ; [George]108-george rushed upon [it]975-the little wretch . [It]975-the little wretch darted into some fallen corn , but [he]108-george had seen it , and had fallen on it . In an instant [he]108-george was up again , and the little creature was dangling from [his]108-george hand .

[We]968-we returned , panting , sweating , [our]968-we eyes flashing , to the edge of the standing corn . [I]0-i heard [Lettie]116-lettie calling , and turning round saw [Emily]109-emily and [the two children]976-the two children entering [the field]4259-the field as [they]976-the two children passed from [school]497-school .

" There 's another ! "[121-leslie] shouted [Leslie]121-leslie .

[I]0-i saw the oat - tops quiver . " Here ! Here ! "[0-i] [I]0-i yelled . The animal leaped out , and made for the hedge . [George]108-george and [Leslie]121-leslie , who were on that side , dashed off , turned [him]108-george , and [he]108-george coursed back [our]968-we way . [I]0-i headed [him]108-george off to [the father who swept in pursuit for a short distance , but who was too heavy for the work]979-the father who swept in pursuit for a short distance , but who was too heavy for the work . [The little beast]980-the little beast made towards the gate , but this time [Mollie]114-meg , with [her]114-meg hat in [her]114-meg hand and [her]114-meg hair flying , whirled upon [him]108-george , and [she]114-meg and [the little fragile lad]981-the little fragile lad sent [him]108-george back again . The rabbit was getting tired . [It]980-the little beast dodged the sheaves badly , running towards [the top hedge]982-the top hedge . [I]0-i went after [it]980-the little beast . If [I]0-i could have let [myself]0-i fall on [it]980-the little beast [I]0-i could have caught it , but this was impossible to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i merely prevented its dashing through the hole into safety . [It]980-the little beast raced along the hedge bottom . [George]108-george tore after [it]980-the little beast . As [he]108-george was upon [it]980-the little beast , it darted into the hedge . [He]108-george fell flat , and shot [his]108-george hand into the gap . But it had escaped . [He]108-george lay there , panting in great sobs , and looking at [me]0-i with eyes in which excitement and exhaustion struggled like flickering light and darkness . When [he]108-george could speak , [he]108-george said , " Why did n't [you]0-i fall on top of it ? "[108-george]

" [I]0-i could n't , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

[We]983-we returned again . [The two children]976-the two children were peering into the thick corn also . [We]983-we thought there was nothing more . [George]108-george began to mow . As [I]0-i walked round [I]0-i caught sight of a rabbit skulking near the bottom corner of the patch . [Its]980-the little beast ears lay pressed against [its]980-the little beast back ; [I]0-i could see the palpitation of the heart under the brown fur , and [I]0-i could see the shining dark eyes looking at [me]0-i . [I]0-i felt no pity for it , but still [I]0-i could not actually hurt it . [I]0-i beckoned to [the father]465-the father . [He]465-the father ran up , and aimed a blow with the rake . There was a sharp little cry which sent a hot pain through [me]0-i as if [I]0-i had been cut . But the rabbit ran out , and instantly [I]0-i forgot the cry , and gave pursuit , fairly feeling [my]0-i fingers stiffen to choke it . It was all lame . [Leslie]121-leslie was upon it in a moment , and [he]121-leslie almost pulled its head off in [his]121-leslie excitement to kill it .

[I]0-i looked up . [The girls]496-the girls were at the gate , just turning away .

" There are no more , "[465-the father] said [the father]465-the father .

At that instant [Mary]111-annie shouted .

" There 's one down this hole . "[111-annie]

[The hole]988-the hole was too small for [George]108-george to get [his]108-george hand in , so [we]989-we dug it out with the rake handle . The stick went savagely down the hole , and there came a squeak .

" [Mice]178-mice ! "[108-george] said [George]108-george , and as [he]108-george said it [the mother]460-the mother slid out . [Somebody]4142-somebody knocked [her]460-the mother on the back , and the hole was opened out . Little mice seemed to swarm everywhere . It was like killing insects . [We]989-we counted [nine little ones]992-nine little ones lying dead .

" [Poor brute]4357-poor brute , "[108-george] said [George]108-george , looking at [the mother]460-the mother , " What a job [she]460-the mother must have had rearing that lot ! "[108-george] [He]108-george picked [her]460-the mother up , handled [her]460-the mother curiously and with pity . Then [he]108-george said , " Well , [I]108-george may as well finish this to - night ! "[108-george]

[[His]108-george father]630-his father took another scythe from off the hedge , and together [they]995-they soon laid the proud , quivering heads low . [Leslie]121-leslie and [I]0-i tied up as [they]995-they mowed , and soon all was finished .

The beautiful day was flushing to die . Over in the west the mist was gathering bluer . The intense stillness was broken by the rhythmic hum of the engines at [the distant coal - mine]996-the distant coal - mine , as [they]995-they drew up the last bantles of [men]562-men . As [we]989-we walked across [the fields]955-the fields the tubes of stubble tinkled like dulcimers . The scent of the corn began to rise gently . The last cry of the pheasants came from the wood , and the little clouds of birds were gone .

[I]0-i carried a scythe , and [we]989-we walked , pleasantly weary , down [the hill]502-the hill towards [the farm]1000-the farm . [The children]4276-the children had gone [home]4184-home with the rabbits .

When [we]989-we reached [the mill]635-the mill , [we]989-we found [the girls]496-the girls just rising from the table . [Emily]109-emily began to carry away the used pots , and to set clean ones for [us]989-we . [She]109-emily merely glanced at [us]989-we and said [her]109-emily formal greeting . [Lettie]116-lettie picked up a book that lay in the ingle seat , and went to the window . [George]108-george dropped into a chair . [He]108-george had flung off [his]108-george coat , and had pushed back [his]108-george hair . [He]108-george rested [his]108-george great brown arms on the table and was silent for a moment .

" Running like that , "[108-george] [he]108-george said to [me]0-i , passing [his]108-george hand over [his]108-george eyes , " makes [you]0-i more tired than a whole day 's work . [I]108-george do n't think [I]108-george shall do it again . "[108-george]

" The sport 's exciting while it lasts , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie .

" It does [you]1005-her son more harm than the rabbits do [us]4358-us good , "[131-mrs. saxton] said [Mrs. Saxton]131-mrs. saxton .

" Oh , [I]1005-her son do n't know , [mother]4146-mother , "[1005-her son] drawled [[her]131-mrs. saxton son]1005-her son , " it 's a couple of shillings . "[1005-her son]

" And a couple of days off [your]1005-her son life . "[131-mrs. saxton]

" What be that ! "[1005-her son] [he]1005-her son replied , taking a piece of bread and butter , and biting a large piece from it .

" Pour [us]4358-us a drop of tea , "[1005-her son] [he]1005-her son said to [Emily]109-emily .

" [I]109-emily do n't know that [I]109-emily shall wait on [such brutes]4360-such brutes , "[109-emily] [she]109-emily replied , relenting , and flourishing the teapot .

" Oh , "[1005-her son] said [he]1005-her son , taking another piece of bread and butter , " [I]1005-her son 'm not all alone in [my]1005-her son savageness this time . "[1005-her son]

" [Men]562-men are [all brutes]4362-all brutes , "[116-lettie] said [Lettie]116-lettie , hotly , without looking up from [her]116-lettie book .

" [You]1005-her son can tame [us]562-men , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie , in mighty good humour .

[She]109-emily did not reply . [George]108-george began , in that deliberate voice that so annoyed [Emily]109-emily :

" It does make [you]109-emily mad , though , to touch the fur , and not be able to grab [him]1005-her son "[108-george] [he]108-george laughed quietly .

[Emily]109-emily moved off in disgust . [Lettie]116-lettie opened [her]116-lettie mouth sharply to speak , but remained silent .

" [I]121-leslie do n't know , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie . " When it comes to killing it goes against the stomach . "[121-leslie]

" If [you]109-emily can run , "[108-george] said [George]108-george , " [you]109-emily should be able to run to death . When [your]109-emily blood 's up , [you]109-emily do n't hang half way . "[108-george]

" [I]116-lettie think [a man]654-a man is horrible , "[116-lettie] said [Lettie]116-lettie , " who can tear the head off a little mite of a thing like a rabbit , after running it in torture over [a field]4364-a field . "[116-lettie]

" When [he]654-a man is nothing but [a barbarian to begin with]4365-a barbarian to begin with "[109-emily] said [Emily]109-emily .

" If [you]109-emily began to run [yourself]109-emily [you]109-emily 'd be the same , "[108-george] said [George]108-george .

" Why , [women]561-women are cruel enough , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie , with a glance at [Lettie]116-lettie . " Yes , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie continued , " [they]561-women 're cruel enough in [their]561-women way "[121-leslie] another look , and a comical little smile .

" Well , "[108-george] said [George]108-george , " what 's the good finicking ! If [you]109-emily feel like doing a thing [you]109-emily 'd better do it . "[108-george]

" Unless [you]108-george have n't courage , "[109-emily] said [Emily]109-emily , bitingly .

[He]108-george looked up at [her]109-emily with dark eyes , suddenly full of anger .

" But , "[116-lettie] said [Lettie]116-lettie [she]116-lettie could not hold [herself]116-lettie from asking , " Do n't [you]108-george think it 's brutal , now that [you]108-george do think is n't it degrading and mean to run the poor little things down ? "[116-lettie]

" Perhaps it is , "[108-george] [he]108-george replied , " but it was n't an hour ago . "[108-george]

" [You]108-george have no feeling , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said bitterly .

[He]108-george laughed deprecatingly , but said nothing .

[We]1006-we finished tea in silence , [Lettie]116-lettie reading , [Emily]109-emily moving about [the house]563-the house . [George]108-george got up and went out at the end . A moment or two after [we]1006-we heard [him]108-george across [the yard]457-the yard with the milk - buckets , singing " [The Ash Grove]4367-the ash grove . "[108-george]

" [He]108-george does n't care a scrap for anything , "[109-emily] said [Emily]109-emily with accumulated bitterness . [Lettie]116-lettie looked out of the window across [the yard]457-the yard , thinking . [She]116-lettie looked very glum .

After a while [we]1006-we went out also , before the light faded altogether from [the pond]1010-the pond . [Emily]109-emily took [us]1006-we into [the lower garden]1011-the lower garden to get some ripe plums . [The old garden]1012-the old garden was very low . [The soil]1013-the soil was black . The cornbind and goosegrass were clutching at the ancient gooseberry bushes , which sprawled by [the paths]1014-the paths . [The garden]444-the garden was not very productive , save of weeds , and perhaps , tremendous lank artichokes or swollen marrows . But at the bottom , where the end of [the farm buildings]1016-the farm buildings rose high and grey , there was a plum - tree which had been crucified to the wall , and which had broken away and leaned forward from bondage . Now under the boughs were hidden great mist - bloomed , crimson treasures , splendid globes . [I]0-i shook the old , ragged trunk , green , with even the fresh gum dulled over , and the treasures fell heavily , thudding down among the immense rhubarb leaves below . [The girls]496-the girls laughed , and [we]1006-we divided the spoil , and turned back to [the yard]457-the yard . [We]1006-we went down to the edge of [the garden]444-the garden , which skirted [the bottom pond]1020-the bottom pond , a pool chained in a heavy growth of weeds . It was moving with rats , [the father]465-the father had said . The rushes were thick below [us]1006-we ; opposite , the great bank fronted [us]1006-we , with orchard trees climbing [it]1022-it like [a hillside]1023-a hillside . [The lower pond]1024-the lower pond received the overflow from the upper by a tunnel from the deep black sluice .

[Two rats]1025-two rats ran into [the black culvert]1026-the black culvert at [our]1006-we approach . [We]1006-we sat on some piled , mossy stones to watch . The rats came out again , ran a little way , stopped , ran again , listened , were reassured , and slid about freely , dragging [their]1025-two rats long naked tails . Soon six or seven grey beasts were playing round [the mouth of [the culvert]1028-the culvert]1027-the mouth of the culvert , in the gloom . [They]1025-two rats sat and wiped [their]1025-two rats sharp faces , stroking [their]1025-two rats whiskers . Then one would give a little rush and a little squirm of excitement and would jump vertically into the air , alighting on four feet , running , sliding into the black shadow . [One]179-one dropped with an ugly plop into the water , and swam toward [us]1006-we , [the hoary imp]1029-the hoary imp , [his]1029-the hoary imp sharp snout and [his]1029-the hoary imp wicked little eyes moving at [us]1006-we . [Lettie]116-lettie shuddered . [I]0-i threw a stone into the dead pool , and frightened [them]1025-two rats all . But [we]1006-we had frightened [ourselves]1006-we more , so [we]1006-we hurried away , and stamped [our]1006-we feet in relief on the free pavement of [the yard]457-the yard .

[Leslie]121-leslie was looking for [us]1006-we . [He]121-leslie had been inspecting [the yard]457-the yard and the stock under [Mr. Saxton]130-mr. saxton 's supervision .

" Were [you]116-lettie running away from [me]121-leslie ? "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie asked .

" No , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie replied . " [I]116-lettie have been to fetch [you]121-leslie a plum . Look ! "[116-lettie] And [she]116-lettie showed [him]121-leslie two in a leaf .

" They are too pretty to eat ! "[121-leslie] said [he]121-leslie .

" [You]121-leslie have not tasted yet , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie laughed .

" Come , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie said , offering [her]116-lettie [his]121-leslie arm . " Let [us]4368-us go up to [the water]429-the water . "[121-leslie] [She]116-lettie took [his]121-leslie arm .

It was a splendid evening , with the light all thick and yellow lying on [the smooth pond]1032-the smooth pond . [Lettie]116-lettie made [him]121-leslie lift [her]116-lettie on to a leaning bough of willow . [He]121-leslie sat with [his]121-leslie head resting against [her]116-lettie skirts . [Emily]109-emily and [I]0-i moved on . [We]1033-we heard [him]121-leslie murmur something , and [her]116-lettie voice reply , gently , caressingly :

" No let [us]1033-we be still it is all so still [I]116-lettie love it best of all now . "[116-lettie]

[Emily]109-emily and [I]0-i talked , sitting at the base of the alders , a little way on . After an excitement , and in the evening , especially in autumn , one is inclined to be sad and sentimental . [We]1033-we had forgotten that the darkness was weaving . [I]0-i heard in the little distance [Leslie]121-leslie 's voice begin to murmur like a flying beetle that comes not too near . Then , away down in [the yard]457-the yard [George]108-george began singing the old song , " [I]108-george sowed the seeds of love . "[108-george]

This interrupted the flight of [Leslie]121-leslie 's voice , and as the singing came nearer , the hum of low words ceased . [We]1033-we went forward to meet [George]108-george . [Leslie]121-leslie sat up , clasping [his]121-leslie knees , and did not speak . [George]108-george came near , saying :

" The moon is going to rise . "[108-george]

" Let [me]116-lettie get down , "[116-lettie] said [Lettie]116-lettie , lifting [her]116-lettie hands to [him]108-george to help [her]116-lettie . [He]108-george , mistaking [her]116-lettie wish , put [his]108-george hands under [her]116-lettie arms , and set [her]116-lettie gently down , as one would [a child]1035-a child . [Leslie]121-leslie got up quickly , and seemed to hold [himself]121-leslie separate , resenting the intrusion .

" [I]108-george thought [you]4370-you were all four together , "[108-george] said [George]108-george quietly . [Lettie]116-lettie turned quickly at the apology :

" So [we]1036-we were . So [we]1036-we are five now . Is it there the moon will rise ? "[116-lettie]

" Yes [I]109-emily like to see it come over the wood . It lifts slowly up to stare at [you]4370-you . [I]109-emily always think it wants to know something , and [I]109-emily always think [I]109-emily have something to answer , only [I]109-emily do n't know what it is , "[109-emily] said [Emily]109-emily .

Where the sky was pale in the east over the rim of wood came the forehead of the yellow moon . [We]1036-we stood and watched in silence . Then , as the great disc , nearly full , lifted and looked straight upon [us]1036-we , [we]1036-we were washed off [our]1036-we feet in a vague sea of moonlight . [We]1036-we stood with the light like water on [our]1036-we faces . [Lettie]116-lettie was glad , a little bit exalted ; [Emily]109-emily was passionately troubled ; [her]109-emily lips were parted , almost beseeching ; [Leslie]121-leslie was frowning , oblivious , and [George]108-george was thinking , and the terrible , immense moonbeams braided through [his]108-george feeling . At length [Leslie]121-leslie said softly , mistakenly :

" Come along , [dear]4347-dear "[121-leslie] and [he]121-leslie took [her]109-emily arm .

[She]109-emily let [him]121-leslie lead [her]109-emily along [the bank of [the pond]1010-the pond]1037-the bank of the pond , and across the plank over the sluice .

" Do [you]121-leslie know , "[109-emily] [she]109-emily said , as [we]1036-we were carefully descending [the steep bank of [the orchard]1040-the orchard]1039-the steep bank of the orchard , " [I]109-emily feel as if [I]109-emily wanted to laugh , or dance something rather outrageous . "[109-emily]

" Surely not like that now , "[121-leslie] [Leslie]121-leslie replied in a low voice , feeling really hurt .

" [I]121-leslie do though ! [I]121-leslie will race [you]121-leslie to the bottom . "[121-leslie]

" No , no , [dear]4347-dear ! "[121-leslie] [He]121-leslie held [her]109-emily back . When [he]121-leslie came to the wicket leading on to [the front lawns]1041-the front lawns , [he]121-leslie said something to [her]109-emily softly , as [he]121-leslie held the gate .

[I]0-i think [he]121-leslie wanted to utter [his]121-leslie half finished proposal , and so bind [her]109-emily .

[She]109-emily broke free , and , observing the long lawn which lay in grey shadow between the eastern and western glows , [she]109-emily cried :

" Polka ! [a polka one]4373-a polka one can dance a polka when the grass is smooth and short even if there are some fallen leaves . Yes , yes how jolly ! "[109-emily]

[She]109-emily held out [her]109-emily hand to [Leslie]121-leslie , but it was too great a shock to [his]121-leslie mood . So [she]109-emily called to [me]0-i , and there was a shade of anxiety in [her]109-emily voice , lest after all [she]109-emily should be caught in the toils of the night 's sentiment .

" [Pat]129-pat [you]121-leslie 'll dance with [me]0-i [Leslie]121-leslie hates a polka . "[0-i] [I]0-i danced with [her]109-emily . [I]0-i do not know the time when [I]0-i could not polka it seems innate in [one]606-one 's feet , to dance that dance . [We]1043-they went flying round , hissing through the dead leaves . The night , the low hung yellow moon , the pallor of the west , the blue cloud of evening overhead went round and through the fantastic branches of the old laburnum , spinning a little madness . [You]1044-you can not tire [Lettie]116-lettie ; [her]116-lettie feet are wings that beat the air . When at last [I]0-i stayed [her]116-lettie [she]116-lettie laughed as fresh as ever , as [she]116-lettie bound [her]116-lettie hair .

" There ! "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie said to [Leslie]121-leslie , in tones of extreme satisfaction , " that was lovely . Do [you]121-leslie come and dance now . "[116-lettie]

" Not a polka , "[121-leslie] said [he]121-leslie , sadly , feeling the poetry in [his]121-leslie heart insulted by the jigging measure .

" But [one]606-one can not dance anything else on wet grass , and through shuffling dead leaves . [You]121-leslie , [George]108-george ? "[116-lettie]

" [Emily]109-emily says [I]121-leslie jump , "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie replied .

" Come on come on "[1043-they] and in a moment [they]1043-they were bounding across the grass . After a few steps [she]116-lettie fell in with [him]121-leslie , and [they]1043-they spun round the grass . It was true , [he]121-leslie leaped , sprang with large strides , carrying [her]116-lettie with [him]121-leslie . It was a tremendous , irresistible dancing . [Emily]109-emily and [I]0-i must join , making an inner ring . Now and again there was a sense of something white flying near , and wild rustle of draperies , and a swish of disturbed leaves as [they]1043-they whirled past [us]1045-us . Long after [we]1045-us were tired [they]1043-they danced on .

At the end , [he]121-leslie looked big , erect , nerved with triumph , and [she]116-lettie was exhilarated like [a Bacchante]1046-a bacchante .

" Have [you]121-leslie finished ? "[121-leslie] [Leslie]121-leslie asked .

[She]116-lettie knew [she]116-lettie was safe from [his]121-leslie question that day .

" Yes , "[116-lettie] [she]116-lettie panted . " [You]121-leslie should have danced . Give [me]116-lettie [my]116-lettie hat , please . Do [I]116-lettie look very disgraceful ? "[116-lettie]

[He]121-leslie took [her]116-lettie hat and gave it to [her]116-lettie .

" Disgraceful ? "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie repeated .

" Oh , [you]116-lettie are solemn to - night ! What is it ? "[121-leslie]

" Yes , what is it ? "[121-leslie] [he]121-leslie repeated ironically .

" It must be the moon . Now , is [my]116-lettie hat straight ? Tell [me]116-lettie now [you]121-leslie 're not looking . Then put it level . Now then ! Why , [your]121-leslie hands are quite cold , and mine so hot ! [I]116-lettie feel so impish , "[116-lettie] and [she]116-lettie laughed .

" There now [I]116-lettie 'm ready . Do [you]121-leslie notice those little chrysanthemums trying to smell sadly ; when the old moon is laughing and winking through those boughs . What business have [they]4375-they with [their]4375-they sadness ! "[116-lettie] [She]116-lettie took a handful of petals and flung them into the air : " There if [they]4375-they sigh [they]4375-they ask for sorrow [I]116-lettie like things to wink and look wild . "[116-lettie]

CHAPTER VI

THE EDUCATION OF [GEORGE]108-george

As [I]0-i have said , [Strelley Mill]2-strelley mill lies at [the north end of [the long Nethermere valley]1048-the long nethermere valley]1047-the north end of the long nethermere valley . On the northern slopes lay [[its]2-strelley mill pasture and arable lands]1049-its pasture and arable lands . [The shaggy common]1050-the shaggy common , now closed and part of [the estate]1051-the estate , covered the western slope , and [the cultivated land]1052-the cultivated land was bounded on the east by the sharp dip of [the brook course]1053-the brook course , a thread of woodland broadening into a spinney and ending at [the upper pond]1054-the upper pond ; beyond this , on the east , rose [the sharp , wild , grassy hillside]1055-the sharp , wild , grassy hillside , scattered with old trees , ruinous with the gaunt , ragged bones of old hedge - rows , grown into thorn trees . Along the rim of [the hills]1056-the hills , beginning in the northwest , were dark woodlands , which swept round east and south till they raced down in riot to the very edge of [southern Nethermere]1-nethermere , surrounding [[our]1057-our house]1058-our house . From [the eastern hill crest]1059-the eastern hill crest , looking straight across , [you]1060-you could see [the spire of [Selsby Church]15-selsby church]1061-the spire of selsby church , and [a few roofs]1062-a few roofs , and the head - stocks of [the pit]1063-the pit .

So on three sides [the farm]1000-the farm was skirted by woods , the dens of rabbits , and [the common]956-the common held [another warren]1066-another warren .

Now [the squire of [the estate]1051-the estate]1067-the squire of the estate , head of [an ancient , once even famous , but now decayed house]1069-an ancient , once even famous , but now decayed house , loved [his]1067-the squire of the estate rabbits . Unlike the family fortunes , the family tree flourished amazingly ; [Sherwood]180-sherwood could show nothing comparable . Its ramifications were stupendous ; it was more like a banyan than a British oak . How was [the good squire]1070-the good squire to nourish [himself]1070-the good squire and [[his]1070-the good squire lady]1071-his lady , [his]1070-the good squire name , [his]1070-the good squire tradition , and [his]1070-the good squire thirteen lusty branches on [[his]1070-the good squire meagre estates]1072-his meagre estates ? An evil fortune discovered to [him]1070-the good squire that [he]1070-the good squire could sell each of [his]1070-the good squire rabbits , those bits of furry vermin , for a shilling or thereabouts in [Nottingham]16-nottingham ; since which time [the noble family]1073-the noble family subsisted by rabbits .

[Farms]1074-farms were gnawed away ; corn and sweet grass departed from the face of [the hills]1056-the hills ; cattle grew lean , unable to eat the defiled herbage . Then [the farm]1000-the farm became [the home of [a keeper]1078-a keeper]1077-the home of a keeper , and [the country]1079-the country was silent , with no sound of cattle , no clink of horses , no barking of lusty dogs .

But [the squire]1080-the squire loved [his]1080-the squire rabbits . [He]1080-the squire defended [them]1081-them against the snares of [the despairing farmer]1082-the despairing farmer , protected [them]1081-them with gun and notices to quit . How [he]1080-the squire glowed with thankfulness as [he]1080-the squire saw the dishevelled hillside heave when [the gnawing hosts]1083-the gnawing hosts moved on !

" Are [they]1081-them not quails and manna ? "[1080-the squire] said [he]1080-the squire to [[his]1080-the squire sporting guest]1084-his sporting guest , early one Monday morning , as [the high meadow]1085-the high meadow broke into life at the sound of [his]1080-the squire gun . " Quails and manna in [this wilderness]4376-this wilderness ? "[1080-the squire]

" [They]1081-them are , by [Jove]177-jove ! "[1086-the sporting guest] assented [the sporting guest]1086-the sporting guest as [he]1086-the sporting guest took another gun , while [the saturnine keeper]1087-the saturnine keeper smiled grimly .

Meanwhile , [Strelley Mill]2-strelley mill began to suffer under this gangrene . It was [the outpost in [the wilderness]1089-the wilderness]1088-the outpost in the wilderness . It was an understood thing that [none of [[the squire]1080-the squire 's tenants]1092-the squire 's tenants]1090-none of the squire 's tenants had a gun .

" Well , "[1080-the squire] said [the squire]1080-the squire to [Mr. Saxton]130-mr. saxton , " [you]1094-the farmer have [the land]4377-the land for next to nothing next to nothing at a rent really absurd . Surely [the little that the rabbits]4378-the little that the rabbits eat "[1080-the squire]

" It 's not a little come and look for [yourself]1094-the farmer , "[1094-the farmer] replied [the farmer]1094-the farmer . [The squire]1080-the squire made a gesture of impatience .

" What do [you]1094-the farmer want ? "[1080-the squire] [he]1080-the squire inquired .

" Will [you]1094-the farmer wire [me]1080-the squire off ? "[1080-the squire] was the repeated request .

" Wire is what does [Halkett]181-halkett say so much per [yard]4379-yard and it would come to what did [Halkett]181-halkett tell [me]1080-the squire now ? but a large sum . No , [I]1080-the squire ca n't do it . "[1080-the squire]

" Well , [I]1080-the squire ca n't live like this . "[1080-the squire]

" Have another glass of whisky ? Yes , yes , [I]1080-the squire want another glass [myself]1080-the squire , and [I]1080-the squire ca n't drink alone so if [I]1080-the squire am to enjoy [my]1080-the squire glass . That 's it ! Now surely [you]1094-the farmer exaggerate a little . It 's not so bad . "[1080-the squire]

" [I]1080-the squire ca n't go on like it , [I]1080-the squire 'm sure . "[1080-the squire]

" Well , [we]1096-we 'll see about compensation [we]1096-we 'll see . [I]1080-the squire 'll have a talk with [Halkett]181-halkett , and [I]1080-the squire 'll come down and have a look at [you]1094-the farmer . [We]1096-we all find a pinch somewhere it 's nothing but humanity 's heritage . "[1080-the squire]

[I]0-i was born in September , and love it best of all the months . There is no heat , no hurry , no thirst and weariness in corn harvest as there is in the hay . If the season is late , as is usual with [us]1096-we , then mid - September sees the corn still standing in stook . The mornings come slowly . [The earth]1097-the earth is like [a woman married and fading]1098-a woman married and fading ; [she]1097-the earth does not leap up with a laugh for the first fresh kiss of dawn , but slowly , quietly , unexpectantly lies watching the waking of each new day . The blue mist , like memory in the eyes of [a neglected wife]1099-a neglected wife , never goes from [the wooded hill]1100-the wooded hill , and only at noon creeps from [the near hedges]1101-the near hedges . There is no bird to put a song in the throat of morning ; only the crow 's voice speaks during the day . Perhaps there is the regular breathing hush of the scythe even the fretful jar of the mowing machine . But next day , in the morning , all is still again . The lying corn is wet , and when [you]1102-you have bound it , and lift the heavy sheaf to make the stook , the tresses of oats wreathe round each other and droop mournfully .

As [I]0-i worked with [[my]0-i friend]432-my friend through the still mornings [we]1096-we talked endlessly . [I]0-i would give [him]432-my friend the gist of what [I]0-i knew of chemistry , and botany , and psychology . Day after day [I]0-i told [him]432-my friend what [the professors]1104-the professors had told [me]0-i ; of life , of sex and its origins ; of [Schopenhauer]182-schopenhauer and [William James]183-william . [We]1096-we had been [friends]1105-friends for years , and [he]432-my friend was accustomed to [my]0-i talk . But this autumn fruited the first crop of intimacy between [us]1096-we . [I]0-i talked a great deal of poetry to [him]432-my friend , and of rudimentary metaphysics . [He]432-my friend was very good stuff . [He]432-my friend had hardly a single dogma , save that of pleasing [himself]432-my friend . Religion was nothing to [him]432-my friend . So [he]432-my friend heard all [I]0-i had to say with an open mind , and understood the drift of things very rapidly , and quickly made these ideas part of [himself]432-my friend .

[We]1096-we tramped down to dinner with only the clinging warmth of the sunshine for a coat . In this still , enfolding weather a quiet companionship is very grateful . Autumn creeps through everything . The little damsons in the pudding taste of September , and are fragrant with memory . The voices of those at table are softer and more reminiscent than at haytime .

Afternoon is all warm and golden . Oat sheaves are lighter ; they whisper to each other as they freely embrace . The long , stout stubble tinkles as the foot brushes over it ; the scent of the straw is sweet . When the poor , bleached sheaves are lifted out of the hedge , a spray of nodding wild raspberries is disclosed , with belated berries ready to drop ; among the damp grass lush blackberries may be discovered . Then [one]606-one notices that the last bell hangs from the ragged spire of fox - glove . The talk is of [people]601-people , an odd book ; of [one]606-one 's hopes and the future ; of [Canada]17-canada , where work is strenuous , but not life ; where [the plains]1109-the plains are wide , and one is not lapped in [a soft valley]1110-a soft valley , like an apple that falls in [a secluded orchard]1111-a secluded orchard . The mist steals over the face of the warm afternoon . The tying - up is all finished , and it only remains to rear up the fallen bundles into shocks . The sun sinks into a golden glow in the west . The gold turns to red , the red darkens , like a fire burning low , the sun disappears behind the bank of milky mist , purple like the pale bloom on blue plums , and [we]1096-we put on [our]1096-we coats and go [home]4184-home .

In the evening , when the milking was finished , and all the things fed , then [we]1096-we went out to look at the snares . [We]1096-we wandered on across [the stream]1113-the stream and up [the wild hillside]1114-the wild hillside . [Our]1096-we feet rattled through black patches of devil's - bit scabius ; [we]1096-we skirted a swim of thistle - down , which glistened when the moon touched it . [We]1096-we stumbled on through wet , coarse grass , over [soft mole - hills]1115-soft mole - hills and black rabbit - holes . [The hills and woods]1116-the hills and woods cast shadows ; the pools of mist in [the valleys]1117-the valleys gathered the moonbeams in cold , shivery light .

[We]1096-we came to [an old farm that stood on]1118-an old farm that stood on [the level brow of [the hill]502-the hill]1119-the level brow of the hill . [The woods]600-the woods swept away from [it]1118-an old farm that stood on , leaving a great clearing of what was once [cultivated land]1122-cultivated land . The handsome chimneys of [the house]563-the house , silhouetted against a light sky , drew [my]0-i admiration . [I]0-i noticed that there was no light or glow in any window , though [the house]563-the house had only the width of [one room]795-one room , and though the night was only at eight o'clock . [We]1096-we looked at [the long , impressive front]1126-the long , impressive front . Several of the windows had been bricked in , giving a pitiful impression of blindness ; the places where the plaster had fallen off the walls showed blacker in the shadow . [We]1096-we pushed open the gate , and as [we]1096-we walked down [the path]495-the path , weeds and dead plants brushed [our]1096-we ankles . [We]1096-we looked in at a window . [The room]518-the room was lighted also by a window from the other side , through which the moonlight streamed on to the flagged floor , dirty , littered with paper , and wisps of straw . The hearth lay in the light , with all its distress of grey ashes , and piled cinders of burnt paper , and [a child]1035-a child 's headless doll , charred and pitiful . On the border - line of shadow lay a round fur cap [a game - keeper]1130-a game - keeper 's cap . [I]0-i blamed the moonlight for entering [the desolate room]1131-the desolate room ; the darkness alone was decent and reticent . [I]0-i hated the little roses on the illuminated piece of wallpaper , [I]0-i hated that fireside .

With [farmer]1132-farmer 's instinct [George]108-george turned to [the outhouse]1133-the outhouse . [The cow - yard]1134-the cow - yard startled [me]0-i . It was a forest of the tallest nettles [I]0-i have ever seen nettles far taller than [my]0-i six feet . The air was soddened with the dank scent of nettles . As [I]0-i followed [George]108-george along [the obscure brick path]1135-the obscure brick path , [I]0-i felt [my]0-i flesh creep . But [the buildings]1136-the buildings , when [we]1137-we entered [them]1136-the buildings , were in splendid condition ; [they]1136-the buildings had been restored within a small number of years ; [they]1136-the buildings were well - timbered , neat , and cosy . Here and there [we]1137-we saw feathers , bits of animal wreckage , even the remnants of a cat , which [we]1137-we hastily examined by the light of a match . As [we]1137-we entered [the stable]1138-the stable there was an ugly noise , and three great rats half rushed at [us]1137-we and threatened [us]1137-we with [their]1139-their vicious teeth . [I]0-i shuddered , and hurried back , stumbling over a bucket , rotten with rust , and so filled with weeds that [I]0-i thought it part of [the jungle]1140-the jungle . There was a silence made horrible by the faint noises that rats and flying bats give out . [The place]4141-the place was bare of any vestige of corn or straw or hay , only choked with a growth of abnormal weeds . When [I]0-i found [myself]0-i free in [the orchard]1040-the orchard [I]0-i could not stop shivering . There were no apples to be seen overhead between [us]1137-we and the clear sky . Either the birds had caused [them]1143-them to fall , when the rabbits had devoured [them]1143-them , or [someone]1144-someone had gathered the crop .

" This , "[108-george] said [George]108-george bitterly , " is what [the mill]635-the mill will come to . "[108-george]

" After [your]108-george time , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" [My]108-george time [my]108-george time . [I]108-george shall never have a time . "[108-george]

" Laissez faire , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , smiling .

[We]1147-we set off at a swinging pace down [the hill]502-the hill , scattering [the hosts]1149-the hosts . " [Damn brute]4393-damn brute ! "[0-i] [I]0-i ejaculated , bruising [my]0-i knuckles against [the fellow]661-the fellow 's jaw . " Get it off , "[108-george] [he]108-george said , standing still to be cleaned .

[I]0-i did [my]0-i best . Then [we]1160-we walked about [the fields]955-the fields for a time , gloomy , silent , and sore .

Suddenly , as [we]1160-we went by [the pond]1010-the pond - side , [we]1160-we were startled by great , swishing black shadows that swept just above [our]1160-we heads . The swans were flying up for shelter , now that a cold wind had begun to fret [Nethermere]1-nethermere . [They]1163-they swung down on to [the glassy mill - pond]1164-the glassy mill - pond , shaking the moonlight in flecks across the deep shadows ; the night rang with the clacking of their wings on [the water]429-the water ; the stillness and calm were broken ; the moonlight was furrowed and scattered , and broken . The swans , as they sailed into shadow , were dim , haunting spectres ; the wind found [us]1160-we shivering .

" Do n't [you]0-i wo n't say anything ? "[108-george] [he]108-george asked as [I]0-i was leaving [him]108-george .

About the end of September , [[our]1160-we countryside]1166-our countryside was alarmed by the harrying of sheep by strange dogs . One morning , [the squire]1080-the squire , going the round of [[his]1080-the squire fields]1168-his fields as was [his]1080-the squire custom , to [his]1080-the squire grief and horror found two of [his]1080-the squire sheep torn and dead in the hedge - bottom , and the rest huddled in a corner swaying about in terror , smeared with blood . [The squire]1080-the squire did not recover [his]1080-the squire spirits for days .

There was a report of two grey wolvish dogs . [[The squire]1080-the squire 's keeper]1171-the squire 's keeper had heard yelping in [the fields of [Dr.]18-dr. Collins of [the Abbey]1173-the abbey]1172-the fields of dr. collins of the abbey , about dawn . [Three sheep]1174-three sheep lay soaked in blood when [the labourer]1175-the labourer went to tend the flocks .

Then [the farmers]1176-the farmers took alarm . [Lord]1177-lord , of [the White House farm]1178-the white house farm , intended to put [his]1177-lord sheep in pen , with [his]1177-lord dogs in charge . It was Saturday , however , and [the lads]1179-the lads ran off to [the little travelling theatre that had halted at [Westwold]19-westwold]1180-the little travelling theatre that had halted at westwold . While [they]1179-the lads sat open - mouthed in [the theatre]1181-the theatre , gloriously nicknamed [the " Blood - Tub]4399-the " blood - tub , "[4399-the " blood - tub] watching [heroes]1182-heroes die with much writhing and heaving , and struggling up to say a word , and collapsing without having said it , six of [their]1179-the lads silly sheep were slaughtered in [the field]4259-the field . At [every house]1184-every house [it]1185-it was enquired of the dog ; nowhere had one been loose .

[Mr. Saxton]130-mr. saxton had some thirty sheep on [the Common]20-the common . [George]108-george determined that the easiest thing was for [him]108-george to sleep out with [them]1186-them . [He]108-george built [a shelter of hurdles interlaced with brushwood]1187-a shelter of hurdles interlaced with brushwood , and in the sunny afternoon [we]1188-we collected piles of bracken , browning to the ruddy winter - brown now . [He]108-george slept [there]1189-there for a week , but that week aged [[his]108-george mother]453-his mother like a year . [She]453-his mother was out in the cold morning twilight watching , with [her]453-his mother apron over [her]453-his mother head , for [his]108-george approach . [She]453-his mother did not rest with the thought of [him]108-george out on [the Common]956-the common .

Therefore , on Saturday night [he]108-george brought down [his]108-george rugs , and took up [Gyp]185-gyp to watch in [his]108-george stead . For some time [we]1188-we sat looking at the stars over [the dark hills]1192-the dark hills . Now and then [a sheep]1193-a sheep coughed , or a rabbit rustled beneath the brambles , and [Gyp]185-gyp whined . The mist crept over the gorse - bushes , and the webs on the brambles were white ; [the devil]4305-the devil throws [his]4305-the devil net over the blackberries as soon as [September]186-september 's back is turned , [they]1195-i say .

" [I]108-george saw [two fellows]4400-two fellows go by with bags and nets , "[108-george] said [George]108-george , as [we]1188-we sat looking out of [[his]108-george little shelter]1196-his little shelter .

" [Poachers]4401-poachers , "[1197-i.] said [I.]1197-i. " Did [you]108-george speak to [them]4401-poachers ? "[1197-i.]

" No [they]4401-poachers did n't see [me]1195-i . [I]1195-i was dropping asleep when a rabbit rushed under the blanket , all of a shiver , and a whippet dog after it . [I]1195-i gave the whippet a punch in the neck , and [he]1195-i yelped off . The rabbit stopped with [me]1195-i quite a long time then it went . "[1195-i]

" How did [you]108-george feel ? "[1197-i.]

" [I]1195-i did n't care . [I]1195-i do n't care much what happens just now . [Father]165-father could get along without [me]1195-i , and [mother]4146-mother has [the children]4276-the children . [I]1195-i think [I]1195-i shall emigrate . "[1195-i]

" Why did n't [you]108-george before ? "[1197-i.]

" But [you]108-george 're going ? "[1197-i.]

" [I]1195-i do n't know . [I]1195-i 've not felt the same since that row with [Annable]184-annable . [I]0-i sat at [my]0-i window looking out , trying to get things straight . Mist rose , and wreathed round [Nethermere]1-nethermere , like ghosts meeting and embracing sadly . [I]0-i thought of the time when [[my]0-i friend]432-my friend should not follow the harrow on [[our]1204-our own snug valley side]1205-our own snug valley side , and when [[Lettie]116-lettie 's room]1206-lettie 's room next [mine]0-i should be closed to hide its emptiness , not its joy . [I]0-i wondered what [Lettie]116-lettie would do .

In the morning [I]0-i was up early , when daybreak came with a shiver through [the woods]600-the woods . [I]0-i went out , while the moon still shone sickly in the west . [The world]1209-the world shrank from the morning . It was then that the last of the summer things died . The wood was dark , and smelt damp and heavy with autumn . On the paths the leaves lay clogged .

As [I]0-i came near [the farm]1000-the farm [I]0-i heard the yelling of dogs . Running , [I]0-i reached [the Common]956-the common , and saw the sheep huddled and scattered in groups , something leaped round [them]1212-them . [George]108-george burst into sight pursuing . Directly , there was the bang , bang of a gun . [I]0-i picked up a heavy piece of sandstone and ran forwards . Three sheep scattered wildly before [me]0-i . In the dim light [I]0-i saw [their]1212-them grey shadows move among the gorse bushes . Then a dog leaped , and [I]0-i flung [my]0-i stone with all [my]0-i might . [I]0-i hit . There came a high - pitched howling yelp of pain ; [I]0-i saw [the brute]1213-the brute make off , and went after [him]1213-the brute , dodging the prickly bushes , leaping the trailing brambles . The gunshots rang out again , and [I]0-i heard [the men]1214-the men shouting with excitement . [My]0-i dog was out of sight , but [I]0-i followed still , slanting down [the hill]502-the hill . In a field ahead [I]0-i saw [someone]1144-someone running . Leaping the low hedge , [I]0-i pursued , and overtook [Emily]109-emily , who was hurrying as fast as [she]109-emily could through the wet grass . There was another gunshot and great shouting . [Emily]109-emily glanced round , saw [me]0-i , and started .

" It 's gone to [the quarries]4418-the quarries , "[109-emily] [she]109-emily panted . [We]1217-we walked on , without saying a word . [The old excavations]1220-the old excavations were filled now with trees . The steep walls , twenty feet deep in places , were packed with loose stones , and trailed with hanging brambles . [We]1217-we climbed down [the steep bank of [the brook]574-the brook]1221-the steep bank of the brook , and entered [the quarries]4418-the quarries by [the bed of [the stream]1113-the stream]1224-the bed of the stream . Under the groves of ash and oak a pale primrose still lingered , glimmering wanly beside the hidden water . [Emily]109-emily found a smear of blood on a beautiful trail of yellow convolvulus . [We]1217-we followed [the tracks]1226-the tracks on to the open , where [the brook]574-the brook flowed on the hard rock bed , and the stony floor of [the quarry]1228-the quarry was only a tangle of gorse and bramble and honeysuckle .

" Take a good stone , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , and [we]1217-we pressed on , where the grove in [the great excavation]1229-the great excavation darkened again , and [the brook]574-the brook slid secretly under the arms of the bushes and the hair of the long grass . [We]1217-we beat the cover almost to [the road]738-the road . " [I]109-emily love beechnuts , "[109-emily] [she]109-emily said , " but they make [me]109-emily long for [my]109-emily childhood again till [I]109-emily could almost cry out . [We]1242-we followed [the soft , smooth - bitten turf road]1243-the soft , smooth - bitten turf road under the old beeches . [One of [the three houses]1250-the three houses]1249-one of the three houses was inhabited . Clear water trickled through a wooden runnel into a great stone trough outside near the door .

[A woman]881-a woman came to the door . One breast was bare , and hung over [her]881-a woman blouse , which , like a dressing - jacket , fell loose over [her]881-a woman skirt . [We]1257-us entered , taking the forgotten kettle lid . [The kitchen]451-the kitchen was large , but scantily furnished save , indeed , for [children]1260-children . [The eldest]1261-the eldest , [a girl of twelve or so]1262-a girl of twelve or so , was standing toasting a piece of bacon with one hand , and holding back [her]1261-the eldest nightdress in the other .
