" Not come down to tea ! "[2696-the black - bearded man] [he]2696-the black - bearded man exclaimed , full of reproach and amazement . " Why , what will [they]2699-they say ? "[2696-the black - bearded man]

" No , [I]813-the woman wo n't come down let [me]813-the woman say farewell ' jamque [Vale]65-vale ! Do [you]2696-the black - bearded man remember how [Eurydice]333-eurydice sank back into [Hell]66-hell ? "[813-the woman]

" But "[2696-the black - bearded man] [he]2696-the black - bearded man stammered , " [you]2696-the black - bearded man must come down to tea how can [I]2696-the black - bearded man tell [them]2699-they ? Why wo n't [you]2696-the black - bearded man come ? "[2696-the black - bearded man]

[She]813-the woman answered [him]2696-the black - bearded man in Latin , with two lines from [Virgil]334-virgil . As [she]813-the woman watched [him]2696-the black - bearded man , [she]813-the woman pitied [his]2696-the black - bearded man helplessness , and gave [him]2696-the black - bearded man a last cut as [she]813-the woman said , very softly and tenderly :

" It would n't be fair to [Meg]114-meg . "[813-the woman]

[He]2696-the black - bearded man stood looking at [her]813-the woman ; [his]2696-the black - bearded man face was coloured only by the grey - brown tan ; [his]2696-the black - bearded man eyes , the dark , self - mistrustful eyes of [the family]2284-the family , were darker than ever , dilated with misery of helplessness ; and [she]813-the woman was infinitely pitiful . [She]813-the woman wanted to cry in [her]813-the woman yearning .

" Shall [we]2707-they go into [the wood]504-the wood for a few minutes ? "[813-the woman] [she]813-the woman said in a low , tremulous voice , as [they]2707-they turned aside .

[The wood]504-the wood was high and warm . Along [the ridings]2709-the ridings [the forget - me - nots]2710-the forget - me - nots were knee deep , stretching , glimmering into the distance like the Milky Way through the night . [They]2707-they left [the tall , flower - tangled paths]2711-the tall , flower - tangled paths to go in among the bluebells , breaking through the close - pressed flowers and ferns till [they]2707-they came to an oak which had fallen across the hazels , where [they]2707-they sat half screened . The hyacinths drooped magnificently with an overweight of purple , or [they]2707-they stood pale and erect , like unripe ears of purple corn . Heavy bees swung down in a blunder of extravagance among the purple flowers . [They]2707-they were intoxicated even with the sight of so much blue . The sound of [their]2707-they hearty , wanton humming came clear upon the solemn boom of the wind overhead . The sight of [their]2707-they clinging , clambering riot gave satisfaction to the soul . A rosy campion flower caught the sun and shone out . An elm sent down a shower of flesh - tinted sheaths upon [them]2707-they .

" If there were fauns and [hamadryads]5228-hamadryads ! "[813-the woman] [she]813-the woman said softly , turning to [him]2712-his to soothe [his]2712-his misery . [She]813-the woman took [his]2712-his cap from [his]2712-his head , ruffled [his]2712-his hair , saying :

" If [you]2712-his were [a faun]5229-a faun , [I]813-the woman would put guelder roses round [your]2712-his hair , and make [you]2712-his look Bacchanalian . "[813-the woman] [She]813-the woman left [her]813-the woman hand lying on [his]2712-his knee , and looked up at the sky . [Its]2713-its blue looked pale and green in comparison with the purple tide ebbing about [the wood]504-the wood . The clouds rose up like towers , and something had touched them into beauty , and poised them up among the winds . The clouds passed on , and the pool of sky was clear .

" Look , "[813-the woman] [she]813-the woman said , " how [we]5230-us are netted down boughs with knots of green buds . If [we]5230-us were free on the winds ! But [I]813-the woman 'm glad [we]5230-us 're not . "[813-the woman] [She]813-the woman turned suddenly to [him]2712-his , and with the same movement , [she]813-the woman gave [him]2712-his [her]813-the woman hand , and [he]2712-his clasped it in both [his]2712-his . " [I]813-the woman 'm glad [we]5230-us 're netted down here ; if [we]5230-us were free in the winds Ah ! "[813-the woman]

[She]813-the woman laughed a peculiar little laugh , catching [her]813-the woman breath .

" Look ! "[813-the woman] [she]813-the woman said , " it 's [a palace]5231-a palace , with the ash - trunks smooth like [a girl]4168-a girl 's arm , and the elm - columns , ribbed and bossed and fretted , with the great steel shafts of beech , all rising up to hold an embroidered care - cloth over [us]5230-us ; and every thread of the care - cloth vibrates with music for [us]5230-us , and the little broidered birds sing ; and the hazel - bushes fling green spray round [us]5230-us , and the honeysuckle leans down to pour out scent over [us]5230-us . Look at the harvest of bluebells ripened for [us]5230-us ! Listen to the bee , sounding among all the organ - play if [he]5233-he sounded exultant for [us]5230-us ! "[813-the woman] [She]813-the woman looked at [him]2712-his , with tears coming up into [her]813-the woman eyes , and a little , winsome , wistful smile hovering round [her]813-the woman mouth . [He]2712-his was very pale , and dared not look at [her]813-the woman . [She]813-the woman put [her]813-the woman hand in [his]2712-his , leaning softly against [him]2712-his . [He]2712-his watched , as if fascinated , a young thrush with full pale breast who hopped near to look at [them]2715-them glancing with quick , shining eyes .

" The clouds are going on again , "[313-lettie] said [Lettie]313-lettie .

" Look at that cloud face see gazing right up into the sky . The lips are opening [he]2712-his is telling [us]5230-us something . now the form is slipping away it 's gone come , [we]5230-us must go too . "[313-lettie]

" No , "[2712-his] [he]2712-his cried , " do n't go do n't go away . "[2712-his]

[Her]813-the woman tenderness made [her]813-the woman calm . [She]813-the woman replied in a voice perfect in restrained sadness and resignation .

" No , [[my]813-the woman dear]4165-my dear , no . The threads of [my]813-the woman life were untwined ; they drifted about like floating threads of gossamer ; and [you]2712-his did n't put out [your]2712-his hand to take them and twist them up into the chord with [yours]2712-his . Now another has caught them up , and the chord of [my]813-the woman life is being twisted , and [I]813-the woman can not wrench it free and untwine it again [I]813-the woman ca n't . [I]813-the woman am not strong enough . Besides , [you]2712-his have twisted another thread far and tight into [your]2712-his chord ; could [you]2712-his get free ? "[813-the woman]

" Tell [me]813-the woman what to do yes , if [you]2712-his tell [me]813-the woman . "[813-the woman]

" [I]813-the woman ca n't tell [you]2712-his so let [me]813-the woman go . "[813-the woman]

" No , [Lettie]313-lettie , "[2716-he] [he]2716-he pleaded , with terror and humility . " No , [Lettie]313-lettie ; do n't go . What should [I]2716-he do with [my]2716-he life ? [Nobody]4176-nobody would love [you]2717-she like [I]2716-he do and what should [I]2716-he do with [my]2716-he love for [you]2717-she ? hate it and fear it , because it 's too much for [me]2716-he ? "[2716-he]

[She]2717-she turned and kissed [him]2716-he gratefully . [He]2716-he then took [her]2717-she in a long , passionate embrace , mouth to mouth . In the end it had so wearied [her]2717-she that [she]2717-she could only wait in [his]2716-he arms till [he]2716-he was too tired to hold [her]2717-she . [He]2716-he was trembling already .

" [Poor Meg]114-meg ! "[2717-she] [she]2717-she murmured to [herself]2717-she dully , [her]2717-she sensations having become vague .

[He]2716-he winced , and the pressure of [his]2716-he arms slackened . [She]2717-she loosened [his]2716-he hands and rose half dazed from [her]2717-she seat by [him]2716-he . [She]2717-she left [him]2716-he , while [he]2716-he sat dejected , raising no protest .

When [I]0-i went out to look for [them]2718-them , when tea had already been waiting on the table half an hour or more , [I]0-i found [him]2716-he leaning against the gatepost at [the bottom of [the hill]502-the hill]2719-the bottom of the hill . There was no blood in [his]2716-he face , and [his]2716-he tan showed livid ; [he]2716-he was haggard as if [he]2716-he had been ill for some weeks .

" Whatever 's the matter ? "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " Where 's [Lettie]313-lettie ? "[0-i]

" [She]5236-she 's gone [home]4184-home , "[2716-he] [he]2716-he answered , and the sound of [his]2716-he own voice , and the meaning of [his]2716-he own words made [him]2716-he heave .

" Why ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked in alarm .

[He]2716-he looked at [me]0-i as if to say " What are [you]0-i talking about ? [I]2716-he can not listen ! "[2716-he]

" Why ? "[0-i] [I]0-i insisted .

" [I]2716-he do n't know , "[2716-he] [he]2716-he replied .

" [They]5238-they are waiting tea for [you]2716-he , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

[He]2716-he heard [me]0-i , but took no notice .

" Come on , "[0-i] [I]0-i repeated , " there 's [Meg]114-meg and [everybody]1611-everybody waiting tea for [you]2716-he . "[0-i]

" [I]2716-he do n't want any , "[2716-he] [he]2716-he said .

[I]0-i waited a minute or two . [He]2716-he was violently sick .

" Vae meum Fervens difficile bile tumet jecur "[0-i]

[I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i .

When the sickness passed over , [he]2716-he stood up away from the post , trembling and lugubrious . [His]2716-he eyelids drooped heavily over [his]2716-he eyes , and [he]2716-he looked at [me]0-i , and smiled a faint , sick smile .

" Come and lie down in [the loft]5240-the loft , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " and [I]0-i 'll tell [them]5241-them [you]2716-he 've got a bilious bout . "[0-i]

[He]2716-he obeyed [me]0-i , not having energy to question ; [his]2716-he strength had gone , and [his]2716-he splendid physique seemed shrunken ; [he]2716-he walked weakly . [I]0-i looked away from [him]2716-he , for in [his]2716-he feebleness [he]2716-he was already beginning to feel ludicrous .

[We]2721-we got into [the barn]589-the barn unperceived , and [I]0-i watched [him]2716-he climb the ladder to [the loft]5240-the loft . Then [I]0-i went [indoors]626-indoors to tell [them]2725-them .

[I]0-i told [them]2725-them [Lettie]313-lettie had promised to be at Highclose for tea , that [George]313-lettie had a bilious attack , and was mooning about [the barn]589-the barn till it was over ; [he]313-lettie had been badly sick . [We]2721-we ate tea without zest or enjoyment . [Meg]114-meg was wistful and ill at ease ; [the father]465-the father talked to [her]114-meg and made much of [her]114-meg ; [the mother]460-the mother did not care for [her]114-meg much .

" [I]460-the mother ca n't understand it , "[460-the mother] said [the mother]460-the mother , " [he]313-lettie so rarely has anything the matter with [him]313-lettie why , [I]460-the mother 've hardly known the day ! Are [you]0-i sure it 's nothing serious , [Cyril]113-cyril ? It seems such a thing and just when [Meg]114-meg happened to be down just when [Meg]114-meg was coming "[460-the mother]

About half - past six [I]0-i had again to go and look for [him]313-lettie , to satisfy the anxiety of [[his]313-lettie mother]453-his mother and [[his]313-lettie sweetheart]2731-his sweetheart . [I]0-i went whistling to let [him]313-lettie know [I]0-i was coming . [He]313-lettie lay on a pile of hay in a corner , asleep . [He]313-lettie had put [his]313-lettie cap under [his]313-lettie head to stop the tickling of the hay , and [he]313-lettie lay half curled up , sleeping soundly . [He]313-lettie was still very pale , and there was on [his]313-lettie face the repose and pathos that a sorrow always leaves . As [he]313-lettie wore no coat [I]0-i was afraid [he]313-lettie might be chilly , so [I]0-i covered [him]313-lettie up with a couple of sacks , and [I]0-i left [him]313-lettie . [I]0-i would not have [him]313-lettie disturbed [I]0-i helped [the father]465-the father about [the cowsheds]2733-the cowsheds , and with the pigs .

[Meg]114-meg had to go at half - past seven . [She]114-meg was so disappointed that [I]0-i said :

" Come and have a look at [him]313-lettie [I]0-i 'll tell [him]313-lettie [you]114-meg did . "[0-i]

[He]313-lettie had thrown off the sacks and spread out [his]313-lettie limbs . As [he]313-lettie lay on [his]313-lettie back , flung out on the hay , [he]313-lettie looked big again , and manly . [His]313-lettie mouth had relaxed , and taken its old , easy lines . [One]606-one felt for [him]313-lettie now the warmth one feels for [anyone who sleeps in an attitude of abandon]2735-anyone who sleeps in an attitude of abandon . [She]114-meg leaned over [him]313-lettie , and looked at [him]313-lettie with a little rapture of love and tenderness ; [she]114-meg longed to caress [him]313-lettie . Then [he]313-lettie stretched [himself]313-lettie , and [his]313-lettie eyes opened . [Their]2736-their sudden unclosing gave [her]114-meg a thrill . [He]313-lettie smiled sleepily , and murmured , " Allo , [Meg]114-meg ! "[313-lettie] Then [I]0-i saw [him]313-lettie awake . As [he]313-lettie remembered , [he]313-lettie turned with a great sighing yawn , hid [his]313-lettie face again , and lay still .

" Come along , [Meg]114-meg , "[0-i] [I]0-i whispered , " [he]313-lettie 'll be best asleep . "[0-i]

" [I]114-meg 'd better cover [him]313-lettie up , "[114-meg] [she]114-meg said , taking the sack and laying it very gently over [his]313-lettie shoulders . [He]313-lettie kept perfectly still while [I]0-i drew [her]114-meg away .

CHAPTER VIII

A POEM OF FRIENDSHIP

The magnificent promise of spring was broken before the May - blossom was fully out . All through the beloved month the wind rushed in upon [us]2737-us from [the north]2203-the north and [north - east]2739-north - east , bringing the rain fierce and heavy . The tender - budded trees shuddered and moaned ; when the wind was dry , the young leaves flapped limp . The grass and corn grew lush , but the light of the dandelions was quite extinguished , and it seemed that only a long time back had [we]2737-us made merry before the broad glare of these flowers . The bluebells lingered and lingered ; they fringed [the fields]955-the fields for weeks like purple fringe of mourning . The pink campions came out only to hang heavy with rain ; hawthorn buds remained tight and hard as pearls , shrinking into the brilliant green foliage ; the forget - me - nots , the poor pleiades of the wood , were ragged weeds . Often at the end of the day the sky opened , and stately clouds hung over the horizon infinitely far away , glowing , through the yellow distance , with an amber lustre . [They]2741-they never came any nearer , always [they]2741-they remained far off , looking calmly and majestically over [the shivering earth]2742-the shivering earth , then saddened , fearing their radiance might be dimmed , [they]2741-they drew away , and sank out of sight . Sometimes , towards sunset , a great shield stretched dark from the west to the zenith , tangling the light along its edges . As the canopy rose higher , it broke , dispersed , and the sky was primrose coloured , high and pale above the crystal moon . Then the cattle crouched among the gorse , distressed by the cold , while the long - billed snipe flickered round high overhead , round and round in great circles , seeming to carry a serpent from its throat , and crying a tragedy , more painful than the poignant lamentations and protests of [the peewits]2121-the peewits . Following these evenings came mornings cold and grey .

Such a morning [I]0-i went up to [George]313-lettie , on the top fallow . [[His]313-lettie father]630-his father was out with the milk [he]630-his father was alone ; as [I]0-i came up [the hill]502-the hill [I]0-i could see [him]313-lettie standing in [the cart]1628-the cart , scattering manure over [the bare red fields]2747-the bare red fields ; [I]0-i could hear [his]313-lettie voice calling now and then to the mare , and the creak and clank of [the cart]1628-the cart as [it]1628-the cart moved on . Starlings and smart wagtails were running briskly over the clods , and many little birds flashed , fluttered , hopped here and there . The lapwings wheeled and cried as ever between the low clouds and [the earth]1097-the earth , and some ran beautifully among the furrows , too graceful and glistening for [the rough field]2750-the rough field .

[I]0-i took a fork and scattered the manure along the hollows , and thus [we]2751-we worked , with a wide field between [us]2751-we , yet very near in the sense of intimacy . [I]0-i watched [him]313-lettie through [the wheeling peewits]2752-the wheeling peewits , as the low clouds went stealthily overhead . Beneath [us]2751-we , the spires of the poplars in [the spinney]1218-the spinney were warm gold , as if the blood shone through . Further gleamed the grey water , and below it the red roofs . [Nethermere]1-nethermere was half hidden and far away . There was nothing in [this grey , lonely world]2754-this grey , lonely world but [the peewits swinging and crying]2755-the peewits swinging and crying , and [George]313-lettie swinging silently at [his]313-lettie work . The movement of active life held all [my]0-i attention , and when [I]0-i looked up , it was to see the motion of [his]313-lettie limbs and [his]313-lettie head , the rise and fall of [his]313-lettie rhythmic body , and the rise and fall of [the slow waving peewits]2756-the slow waving peewits . After a while , when the cart was empty , [he]313-lettie took a fork and came towards [me]0-i , working at [my]0-i task .

It began to rain , so [he]313-lettie brought a sack from the cart , and [we]2751-we crushed [ourselves]2751-we under the thick hedge . [We]2751-we sat close together and watched the rain fall like a grey striped curtain before [us]2751-we , hiding [the valley]425-the valley ; [we]2751-we watched it trickle in dark streams off [the mare]5077-the mare 's back , as [she]5077-the mare stood dejectedly ; [we]2751-we listened to the swish of the drops falling all about ; [we]2751-we felt the chill of the rain , and drew [ourselves]2751-we together in silence . [He]313-lettie smoked [his]313-lettie pipe , and [I]0-i lit a cigarette . The rain continued ; all the little pebbles and the red earth glistened in the grey gloom . [We]2751-we sat together , speaking occasionally . It was at these times [we]2751-we formed the almost passionate attachment which later years slowly wore away .

When the rain was over , [we]2751-we filled [our]2751-we buckets with potatoes , and went along the wet furrows , sticking the spritted tubers in the cold ground . Being sandy , [the field]4259-the field dried quickly . About twelve o'clock , when nearly all the potatoes were set , [he]313-lettie left [me]0-i , and fetching up [Bob]335-bob from the far hedge - side , harnessed the mare and [him]335-bob to [the ridger]2760-the ridger , to cover the potatoes . The sharp light plough turned the soil in a fine furrow over the potatoes ; hosts of little birds fluttered , settled , bounded off again after the plough . [He]313-lettie called to the horses , and [they]2761-they came downhill , the white stars on the two brown noses nodding up and down , [George]313-lettie striding firm and heavy behind . [They]2761-they came down upon [me]0-i ; at a call the horses turned , shifting awkwardly sideways ; [he]313-lettie flung [himself]313-lettie against the plough , and leaning well in , brought it round with a sweep : a click , and [they]2761-they are off uphill again . There is a great rustle as the birds sweep round after [him]313-lettie and follow up the new turned furrow . Untackling the horses when the rows were all covered , [we]2751-we tramped behind [them]2761-they down [the wet hillside]2762-the wet hillside to dinner .

[I]0-i kicked through the drenched grass , crushing the withered cowslips under [my]0-i clogs , avoiding the purple orchids that were stunted with harsh upbringing , but magnificent in their powerful colouring , crushing the pallid lady smocks , the washed - out wild gillivers . [I]0-i became conscious of something near [my]0-i feet , something little and dark , moving indefinitely . [I]0-i had found again the larkie 's nest . [I]0-i perceived the yellow beaks , the bulging eyelids of two tiny larks , and the blue lines of [their]2761-they wing quills . The indefinite movement was the swift rise and fall of the brown fledged backs , over which waved long strands of fine down . The two little specks of birds lay side by side , beak to beak , [their]2761-they tiny bodies rising and falling in quick unison . [I]0-i gently put down [my]0-i fingers to touch them ; they were warm ; gratifying to find [them]2761-they warm , in the midst of so much cold and wet . [I]0-i became curiously absorbed in them , as an eddy of wind stirred the strands of down . When [one fledgling]2763-one fledgling moved uneasily , shifting [his]2763-one fledgling soft ball , [I]0-i was quite excited ; but [he]2763-one fledgling nestled down again , with [his]2763-one fledgling head close to [[his]2763-one fledgling brother]4289-his brother 's . In [my]0-i heart of hearts , [I]0-i longed for [someone to nestle against]2765-someone to nestle against , [someone who would come between [me]0-i and [the coldness and wetness of the surroundings]2767-the coldness and wetness of the surroundings]2766-someone who would come between me and the coldness and wetness of the surroundings . [I]0-i envied [the two little miracles exposed to any tread , yet so serene]2768-the two little miracles exposed to any tread , yet so serene . It seemed as if [I]0-i were always wandering , looking for something which [they]2768-the two little miracles exposed to any tread , yet so serene had found even before the light broke into [their]2768-the two little miracles exposed to any tread , yet so serene shell . [I]0-i was cold ; the lilacs in [the Mill garden]2769-the mill garden looked blue and perished . [I]0-i ran with [my]0-i heavy clogs and [my]0-i heart heavy with vague longing , down to [the Mill]635-the mill , while the wind blanched the sycamores , and pushed the sullen pines rudely , for the pines were sulking because their million creamy sprites could not fly wet - winged . The horse - chestnuts bravely kept [their]2771-their white candles erect in the socket of every bough , though no sun came to light them . Drearily a cold swan swept up [the water]429-the water , trailing its black feet , clacking its great hollow wings , rocking the frightened water hens , and insulting the staid black - necked geese . What did [I]0-i want that [I]0-i turned thus from one thing to another ?

At the end of June the weather became fine again . Hay harvest was to begin as soon as it settled . There were only [two fields to be mown]2773-two fields to be mown this year , to provide just enough stuff to last until the spring . As [my]0-i vacation had begun [I]0-i decided [I]0-i would help , and that [we]2774-we three , [the father]465-the father , [George]313-lettie and [I]0-i , would get in the hay without hired assistance .

[I]0-i rose the first morning very early , before the sun was well up . The clear sound of challenging cocks could be heard along [the valley]425-the valley . In [the bottoms]2777-the bottoms , over [the water]429-the water and over the lush wet grass , the night mist still stood white and substantial . As [I]0-i passed along [the edge of [the meadow]1366-the meadow]2779-the edge of the meadow [the cow - parsnip]2781-the cow - parsnip was as tall as [I]0-i , frothing up to the top of the hedge , putting the faded hawthorn to a wan blush . Little , early birds [I]0-i had not heard the lark fluttered in and out of [the foamy meadow - sea]2782-the foamy meadow - sea , plunging under the surf of flowers washed high in one corner , swinging out again , dashing past the crimson sorrel cresset . Under the froth of flowers were the purple vetch - clumps , yellow milk vetches , and the scattered pink of the wood - betony , and the floating stars of marguerites . There was a weight of honeysuckle on the hedges , where pink roses were waking up for their broad - spread flight through the day .

Morning silvered the swaths of [the far meadow]2783-the far meadow , and swept in smooth , brilliant curves round the stones of [the brook]574-the brook ; morning ran in [my]0-i veins ; morning chased the silver , darting fish out of the depth , and [I]0-i , who saw them , snapped [my]0-i fingers at them , driving them back .

[I]0-i heard [Trip]110-trip barking , so [I]0-i ran towards [the pond]1010-the pond . [The punt]2786-the punt was at [the island]2787-the island , where from behind the bushes [I]0-i could hear [George]313-lettie whistling . [I]0-i called to [him]313-lettie , and [he]313-lettie came to [the water]429-the water 's edge half dressed .

" Fetch a towel , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie called , " and come on . "[313-lettie]

[I]0-i was back in a few moments , and there stood [my]0-i Charon fluttering in the cool air . One good push sent [us]2789-us to [the islet]2790-the islet [I]0-i made haste to undress , for [he]313-lettie was ready for [the water]429-the water , [Trip]110-trip dancing round , barking with excitement at [his]313-lettie new appearance .

" [He]313-lettie wonders what 's happened to [me]313-lettie , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , laughing , pushing the dog playfully away with [his]313-lettie bare foot . [Trip]110-trip bounded back , and came leaping up , licking [him]313-lettie with little caressing licks . [He]313-lettie began to play with the dog , and directly [they]2789-us were rolling on the fine turf , [the laughing , expostulating , naked man]2792-the laughing , expostulating , naked man , and the excited dog , who thrust [his]313-lettie great head on to [the man]655-the man 's face , licking , and , when flung away , rushed forward again , snapping playfully at the naked arms and breasts . At last [George]313-lettie lay back , laughing and panting , holding [Trip]110-trip by the two fore feet which were planted on [his]313-lettie breast , while the dog , also panting , reached forward [his]313-lettie head for a flickering lick at the throat pressed back on the grass , and the mouth thrown back out of reach . When [the man]655-the man had thus lain still for a few moments , and the dog was just laying [his]313-lettie head against [[his]313-lettie master]2795-his master 's neck to rest too , [I]0-i called , and [George]313-lettie jumped up , and plunged into [the pond]1010-the pond with [me]0-i , [Trip]110-trip after [us]2797-us .

The water was icily cold , and for a moment deprived [me]0-i of [my]0-i senses . When [I]0-i began to swim , soon [the water]429-the water was buoyant , and [I]0-i was sensible of nothing but the vigorous poetry of action . [I]0-i saw [George]313-lettie swimming on [his]313-lettie back laughing at [me]0-i , and in an instant [I]0-i had flung [myself]0-i like an impulse after [him]313-lettie . The laughing face vanished as [he]313-lettie swung over and fled , and [I]0-i pursued the dark head and the ruddy neck . [Trip]110-trip , [the wretch]2799-the wretch , came paddling towards [me]0-i , interrupting [me]0-i ; then all bewildered with excitement , [he]110-trip scudded to [the bank]434-the bank . [I]0-i chuckled to [myself]0-i as [I]0-i saw [him]110-trip run along , then plunge in and go plodding to [George]313-lettie . [I]0-i was gaining . [He]313-lettie tried to drive off the dog , and [I]0-i gained rapidly . As [I]0-i came up to [him]313-lettie and caught [him]313-lettie , with [my]0-i hand on [his]313-lettie shoulder , there came a laughter from [the bank]434-the bank . It was [Emily]109-emily .

[I]0-i trod the water , and threw handfuls of spray at [her]109-emily . [She]109-emily laughed and blushed . Then [Trip]110-trip waded out to [her]109-emily and [she]109-emily fled swiftly from [his]110-trip shower - bath . [George]313-lettie was floating just beside [me]0-i , looking up and laughing .

[We]2802-we stood and looked at [each other]4254-each other as [we]2802-we rubbed [ourselves]2802-we dry . [He]313-lettie was well proportioned , and naturally of handsome physique , heavily limbed . [He]313-lettie laughed at [me]0-i , telling [me]0-i [I]0-i was like [one of [[Aubrey Beardsley]292-aubrey beardsley 's long , lean ugly fellows]2805-aubrey beardsley 's long , lean ugly fellows]2804-one of aubrey beardsley 's long , lean ugly fellows . [I]0-i referred [him]313-lettie to many classic examples of slenderness , declaring [myself]0-i more exquisite than [his]313-lettie grossness , which amused [him]313-lettie .

But [I]0-i had to give in , and bow to [him]313-lettie , and [he]313-lettie took on an indulgent , gentle manner . [I]0-i laughed and submitted . For [he]313-lettie knew how [I]0-i admired the noble , white fruitfulness of [his]313-lettie form . As [I]0-i watched [him]313-lettie , [he]313-lettie stood in white relief against the mass of green . [He]313-lettie polished [his]313-lettie arm , holding it out straight and solid ; [he]313-lettie rubbed [his]313-lettie hair into curls , while [I]0-i watched the deep muscles of [his]313-lettie shoulders , and the bands stand out in [his]313-lettie neck as [he]313-lettie held it firm ; [I]0-i remembered the story of [Annable]184-annable .

[He]313-lettie saw [I]0-i had forgotten to continue [my]0-i rubbing , and laughing [he]313-lettie took hold of [me]0-i and began to rub [me]0-i briskly , as if [I]0-i were [a child]1035-a child , or rather , [a woman [he]313-lettie loved and did not fear]2807-a woman he loved and did not fear . [I]0-i left [myself]0-i quite limply in [his]313-lettie hands , and , to get a better grip of [me]0-i , [he]313-lettie put [his]313-lettie arm round [me]0-i and pressed [me]0-i against [him]313-lettie , and the sweetness of the touch of [our]2808-we naked bodies one against the other was superb . It satisfied in some measure the vague , indecipherable yearning of [my]0-i soul ; and it was the same with [him]313-lettie . When [he]313-lettie had rubbed [me]0-i all warm , [he]313-lettie let [me]0-i go , and [we]2808-we looked at [each other]4254-each other with eyes of still laughter , and [our]2808-we love was perfect for a moment , more perfect than any love [I]0-i have known since , either for [man]4239-man or [woman]4783-woman .

[We]2808-we went together down to [the fields]955-the fields , [he]313-lettie to mow the island of grass [he]313-lettie had left standing the previous evening , [I]0-i to sharpen the machine knife , to mow out the hedge - bottoms with the scythe , and to rake the swaths from the way of the machine when the unmown grass was reduced to a triangle . The cool , moist fragrance of the morning , the intentional stillness of everything , of the tall bluish trees , of the wet , frank flowers , of the trustful moths folded and unfolded in the fallen swaths , was a perfect medium of sympathy . The horses moved with a still dignity , obeying [his]313-lettie commands . When [they]2813-they were harnessed , and the machine oiled , still [he]313-lettie was loth to mar the perfect morning , but stood looking down [the valley]425-the valley .

" [I]313-lettie sha n't mow [these fields]5242-these fields any more , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , and the fallen , silvered swaths flickered back [his]313-lettie regret , and the faint scent of the limes was wistful . So much of [the field]4259-the field was cut , so much remained to cut ; then it was ended . This year the elder flowers were widespread over the corner bushes , and the pink roses fluttered high above the hedge . There were the same flowers in the grass as [we]2808-we had known many years ; [we]2808-we should not know them any more .

" But merely to have mown them is worth having lived for , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , looking at [me]0-i .

[We]2808-we felt the warmth of the sun trickling through the morning 's mist of coolness .

" [You]0-i see that sycamore , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , " that bushy one beyond the big willow ? [I]313-lettie remember when [father]4145-father broke off the leading shoot because [he]4145-father wanted a fine straight stick , [I]313-lettie can remember [I]313-lettie felt sorry . It was running up so straight , with such a fine balance of leaves [you]0-i know how a young strong sycamore looks about nine feet high it seemed a cruelty . When [you]0-i are gone , and [we]2808-we are left from here , [I]313-lettie shall feel like that , as if [my]313-lettie leading shoot were broken off . [You]0-i see , the tree is spoiled . Yet how it went on growing . [I]313-lettie believe [I]313-lettie shall grow faster . [I]313-lettie can remember the bright red stalks of the leaves as [he]313-lettie broke them off from the bough . "[313-lettie]

[He]313-lettie smiled at [me]0-i , half proud of [his]313-lettie speech . Then [he]313-lettie swung into the seat of the machine , having attended to the horses ' heads . [He]313-lettie lifted the knife .

" Good - bye , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , smiling whimsically back at [me]0-i . The machine started . The bed of the knife fell , and the grass shivered and dropped over . [I]0-i watched the heads of the daisies and the splendid lines of the cocksfool grass quiver , shake against the crimson burnet , and drop - over . The machine went singing down [the field]4259-the field , leaving a track of smooth , velvet green in the way of the swath - board . The flowers in the wall of uncut grass waited unmoved , as the days wait for [us]2817-we . The sun caught in the uplicking scarlet sorrel flames , the butterflies woke , and [I]0-i could hear the fine ring of [his]313-lettie " Whoa ! "[313-lettie] from the far corner . Then [he]313-lettie turned , and [I]0-i could see only the tossing ears of the horses , and the white of [his]313-lettie shoulder as [they]2818-they moved along the wall of high grass on [the hill slope]2819-the hill slope . [I]0-i sat down under the elm to file the sections of the knife . Always as [he]313-lettie rode [he]313-lettie watched the falling swath , only occasionally calling the horses into line . It was [his]313-lettie voice which rang the morning awake . When [we]2817-we were at [work]2820-work [we]2817-we hardly noticed [one another]1500-one another . Yet [[his]313-lettie mother]453-his mother had said :

" [George]313-lettie is so glad when [you]313-lettie 're in [the field]4259-the field [he]313-lettie does n't care how long the day is . "[453-his mother]

Later , when the morning was hot , and the honeysuckle had ceased to breathe , and all the other scents were moving in the air about [us]2817-we , when all [the field]4259-the field was down , when [I]0-i had seen the last trembling ecstasy of the harebells , trembling to fall ; when the thick clump of purple vetch had sunk ; when the green swaths were settling , and the silver swaths were glistening and glittering as the sun came along them , in the hot ripe morning [we]2817-we worked together turning the hay , tipping over the yesterday 's swaths with [our]2817-we forks , and bringing yesterday 's fresh , hidden flowers into the death of sunlight .

It was then that [we]2817-we talked of the past , and speculated on the future . As the day grew older and less wistful , [we]2817-we forgot everything , and worked on , singing , and sometimes [I]0-i would recite [him]313-lettie verses as [we]2817-we went , and sometimes [I]0-i would tell [him]313-lettie about books . Life was full of glamour for [us]2817-we both .

CHAPTER IX

[PASTORALS AND PEONIES]2824-pastorals and peonies

At dinner time [the father]465-the father announced to [us]2817-we the exciting fact that [Leslie]121-leslie had asked if [a few of [[his]465-the father guests]2827-his guests]2826-a few of his guests might picnic that afternoon in [the Strelley hayfields]2828-the strelley hayfields . [The closes]2829-the closes were so beautiful , with [the brook]574-the brook under all its sheltering trees , running into [the pond]1010-the pond that was set with [two green islets]2832-two green islets . Moreover , [[the squire]1080-the squire 's lady]2834-the squire 's lady had written a book filling [these meadows]2835-these meadows and [the mill precincts]2836-the mill precincts with pot - pourri romance . [The wedding guests at Highclose]2837-the wedding guests at highclose were anxious to picnic in so choice a spot .

[The father , who delighted in a gay throng]2838-the father , who delighted in a gay throng , beamed at [us]2817-we from over the table . [George]313-lettie asked who were coming .

" Oh , [not many about half a dozen mostly ladies down for the wedding]5245-not many about half a dozen mostly ladies down for the wedding . "[313-lettie]

[George]313-lettie at first swore warmly ; then [he]313-lettie began to appreciate the affair as a joke .

[Mrs. Saxton]131-mrs. saxton hoped [they]2839-they would n't want [her]131-mrs. saxton to provide [them]2839-they pots , for [she]131-mrs. saxton had n't two cups that matched , nor had any of [her]131-mrs. saxton spoons the least pretence to silver . [The children]4276-the children were hugely excited , and wanted a holiday from [school]497-school , which [Emily]109-emily at once vetoed firmly , thereby causing [family]2842-family dissension .

As [we]2817-we went round [the field]4259-the field in the afternoon turning the hay , [we]2817-we were thinking apart , and did not talk . Every now and then and at [every corner]2844-every corner [we]2817-we stopped to look down towards [the wood]504-the wood , to see if [they]2839-they were coming .

" Here [they]2839-they are ! "[313-lettie] [George]313-lettie exclaimed suddenly , having spied the movement of white in [the dark wood]2846-the dark wood . [We]2817-we stood still and watched . [Two girls , heliotrope and white]2847-two girls , heliotrope and white , [a man with two girls , pale green and white]2848-a man with two girls , pale green and white , and [a man]654-a man with [a girl]4168-a girl last .

" Can [you]654-a man tell who [they]2839-they are ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" That 's [Marie Tempest]336-marie , [that first girl in white]5246-that first girl in white , and that 's [him]654-a man and [Lettie]313-lettie at the back , [I]654-a man do n't know any more . "[654-a man]

[He]654-a man stood perfectly still until [they]2839-they had gone out of sight behind the banks down by [the brooks]1476-the brooks , then [he]654-a man stuck [his]654-a man fork in the ground , saying :

" [You]0-i can easily finish if [you]0-i like . [I]654-a man 'll go and mow out that bottom corner . "[654-a man]

[He]654-a man glanced at [me]0-i to see what [I]0-i was thinking of [him]654-a man . [I]0-i was thinking that [he]654-a man was afraid to meet [her]2852-her , and [I]0-i was smiling to [myself]0-i . [I]0-i heard the clanging slur of the scythe stone as [he]654-a man whetted the blade . [I]0-i went to [the pond]1010-the pond to meet [the newcomers]1574-the newcomers . [I]0-i bowed to [Louie Denys]337-louie denys , [a tall , graceful girl of the drooping type]2857-a tall , graceful girl of the drooping type , elaborately gowned in heliotrope linen ; [I]0-i bowed to [Agnes D'Arcy]338-agnes d'arcy , [an erect , intelligent girl with magnificent auburn hair [she]338-agnes d'arcy wore no hat and carried a sunshade]2858-an erect , intelligent girl with magnificent auburn hair she wore no hat and carried a sunshade ; [I]0-i bowed to [Hilda Seconde]339-hilda , [a svelte , petite girl , exquisitely and delicately pretty]2859-a svelte , petite girl , exquisitely and delicately pretty ; [I]0-i bowed to [Maria]336-marie and to [Lettie]313-lettie , and [I]0-i shook hands with [Leslie]121-leslie and with [[his]121-leslie friend]2860-his friend , [Freddy Cresswell]340-cresswell . [The latter]627-the latter was to be [best man]2862-best man , [a broad shouldered , pale - faced fellow , with beautiful soft hair like red wheat , and laughing eyes , and a whimsical , drawling manner of speech]2863-a broad shouldered , pale - faced fellow , with beautiful soft hair like red wheat , and laughing eyes , and a whimsical , drawling manner of speech , like [a man who has suffered enough to bring him to manhood and maturity]2864-a man who has suffered enough to bring him to manhood and maturity , but who in spite of all remains [a boy]4230-a boy , irresponsible , lovable a trifle pathetic . As the day was very hot , [both men]2866-both men were in flannels , and wore flannel collars , yet it was evident that [they]2866-both men had dressed with scrupulous care . Instinctively [I]0-i tried to pull [my]0-i trousers into shape within [my]0-i belt , and [I]0-i felt the inferiority cast upon [the father]465-the father , big and fine as [he]465-the father was in [his]465-the father way , for [his]465-the father shoulders were rounded with work , and [his]465-the father trousers were much distorted .

Do [you]2880-you find much time to sport with Amaryllis in the shade ? [I]2882-the tall , proud girl 'm sure it 's a shame [they]5267-they banished [Phyllis]348-phyllis from [the fields]955-the fields "[2882-the tall , proud girl]

[He]2884-he laughed and went on with [his]2884-he work . [She]2882-the tall , proud girl smiled a little , too , thinking [she]2882-the tall , proud girl had made a great impression . [She]2882-the tall , proud girl put out [her]2882-the tall , proud girl hand with a dramatic gesture , and looked at [me]0-i , when the scythe crunched through [the meadow]1366-the meadow - sweet .

" Crunch ! is n't it fine ! "[2882-the tall , proud girl] [she]2882-the tall , proud girl exclaimed , " a kind of inevitable fate [I]2882-the tall , proud girl think it 's fine ! "[2882-the tall , proud girl]

[We]2886-we wandered about picking flowers and talking until teatime . [A manservant]2887-a manservant came with the tea - basket , and [the girls]496-the girls spread the cloth under a great willow tree . [Lettie]313-lettie took the little silver kettle , and went to fill it at the small spring which trickled into a stone trough all pretty with cranesbill and stellaria hanging over , while long blades of grass waved in the water . [George]313-lettie , who had finished [his]313-lettie work , and wanted to go [home]4184-home to tea , walked across to the spring where [Lettie]313-lettie sat playing with the water , getting little cupfuls to put into the kettle , watching the quick skating of the water beetles , and the large faint spots of [their]496-the girls shadows darting on the silted mud at the bottom of the trough .

[She]2882-the tall , proud girl glanced round on hearing [him]2884-he coming , and smiled nervously : [they]2886-we were mutually afraid of meeting [each other]4254-each other again .

" It is about teatime , "[2884-he] [he]2884-he said .

" Yes it will be ready in a moment this is not to make the tea with it 's only to keep a little supply of hot water . "[2882-the tall , proud girl]

[The girls]496-the girls were seated on tufts of hay , with [the men]1214-the men leaning in attendance on [them]496-the girls , and [the manservant]2893-the manservant waiting on all . " [George]313-lettie , "[2899-they] [they]2899-they said afterwards , " was a wet blanket on the party . "[2899-they] [Lettie]313-lettie was intensely annoyed with [him]2884-he . " Has it run away ? "[339-hilda] laughed [Hilda]339-hilda , delighted and [we]2904-we hastened out of [the lower garden]1011-the lower garden to see .

There in the green shade , between the tall gooseberry bushes , the heavy crimson peonies stood gorgeously along [the path]495-the path . The full red globes , poised and leaning voluptuously , sank their crimson weight on to the seeding grass of [the path]495-the path , borne down by secret rain , and by [their]2900-they own splendour . [The path]495-the path was poured over with red rich silk of strewn petals . The great flowers swung their crimson grandly about [the walk]2910-the walk , like crowds of cardinals in pomp among the green bushes . [We]2904-we burst into the new world of delight . As [Lettie]313-lettie stooped , taking between both hands the gorgeous silken fulness of one blossom that was sunk to the earth . [George]313-lettie came down [the path]495-the path , with the brown bull - calf straddling behind [him]313-lettie , its neck stuck out , sucking zealously at [his]313-lettie middle finger .

The unconscious attitudes of [the girls , all bent enraptured over the peonies]2912-the girls , all bent enraptured over the peonies , touched [him]313-lettie with sudden pain . As [he]313-lettie came up , with the calf stalking grudgingly behind , [he]313-lettie said :

" There 's a fine show of pyeenocks this year , is n't [there]1189-there ? "[313-lettie]

" Pyeenocks , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie replied .

[Lettie]313-lettie remained crouching with a red flower between [her]339-hilda hands , glancing sideways unseen to look at the calf , which with its shiny nose uplifted was mumbling in its sticky gums the seductive finger . It sucked eagerly , but unprofitably , and it appeared to cast a troubled eye inwards to see if it were really receiving any satisfaction , doubting , but not despairing . [Marie]336-marie , and [Hilda]339-hilda , and [Leslie]121-leslie laughed , while [he]313-lettie , after looking at [Lettie]313-lettie as [she]339-hilda crouched , wistfully , as [he]313-lettie thought , over the flower , led [the little brute]2913-the little brute out of [the garden]444-the garden , and sent [it]2913-the little brute running into [the yard]457-the yard with a smack on the haunch .

Then [he]313-lettie returned , rubbing [his]313-lettie sticky finger dry against [his]313-lettie breeches . [He]313-lettie stood near to [Lettie]313-lettie , and [she]339-hilda felt rather than saw the extraordinary pale cleanness of the one finger among the others . " There is a tale about [them]496-the girls , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

[They]5285-they used to tryst in [the poplar spinney]5286-the poplar spinney . " It is a beautiful ending , "[313-lettie] said [Lettie]313-lettie , in a low tone , looking at the floor .

" It 's all a tale , "[121-leslie] said [Leslie]121-leslie , soothing [the girls]496-the girls .

[Marie]336-marie asked for some of the peonies .

Later , when [all]2924-all had gone to bed at [the mill]635-the mill , [George]313-lettie and [I]0-i sat together on opposite sides of the fire , smoking , saying little . " And all day , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , " [Blench]349-blench has been ploughing [his]349-blench wheat in , because it was that bitten off by the rabbits it was no manner of use , so [he]349-blench 's ploughed it in : an ' [they]5290-they say with idylls , eating peaches in [our]2923-we close . "[313-lettie]

Then there was silence , while the clock throbbed heavily , and outside a wild bird called , and was still ; softly the ashes rustled lower in the grate .

" [She]2926-she said it ended well but what 's the good of death what 's the good of that ? "[313-lettie] [He]313-lettie turned [his]313-lettie face to the ashes in the grate , and sat brooding .

" Damn that row ! "[0-i] said [I]0-i , stirring , looking also into the grey fire .

" It is no good , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " Go to bed it will be morning in a few hours . "[0-i]

PART III

CHAPTER I

A NEW START IN LIFE

[Lettie]313-lettie was wedded , as [I]0-i had said , before [Leslie]121-leslie lost all the wistful traces of [his]121-leslie illness . [They]2927-they had been gone away to [France]45-france five days before [we]2928-we recovered anything like the normal tone in [the house]563-the house . Then , though the routine was the same , everywhere was a sense of loss , and of change . The long voyage in [the quiet home]2930-the quiet home was over ; [we]2928-we had crossed [the bright sea of [our]2928-we youth]2931-the bright sea of our youth , and already [Lettie]313-lettie had landed and was travelling to [a strange destination in [a foreign land]2933-a foreign land]2932-a strange destination in a foreign land . It was time for [us]2928-we all to go , to leave [the valley of [Nethermere]1-nethermere whose waters and [whose woods]2935-whose woods were distilled in the essence of [our]2928-we veins]2934-the valley of nethermere whose waters and whose woods were distilled in the essence of our veins . [We]2928-we were [the children of [the valley of [Nethermere]1-nethermere]2937-the valley of nethermere , [a small nation with language and blood of [our]2928-we own]2938-a small nation with language and blood of our own , and to cast [ourselves]2928-we each one into separate exile was painful to [us]2928-we]2936-the children of the valley of nethermere , a small nation with language and blood of our own , and to cast ourselves each one into separate exile was painful to us .

" [I]313-lettie shall have to go now , "[313-lettie] said [George]313-lettie . " It is [my]313-lettie nature to linger an unconscionable time , yet [I]313-lettie dread above all things this slow crumbling away from [my]313-lettie foundations by which [I]313-lettie free [myself]313-lettie at last . [I]313-lettie must wrench [myself]313-lettie away now "[313-lettie]

It was the slack time between the hay and the corn harvest , and [we]2928-we sat together in the grey , still morning of [August]351-august pulling the stack . [My]0-i hands were sore with tugging the loose wisps from the lower part of the stack , so [I]0-i waited for the touch of rain to send [us]2928-we indoors . It came at last , and [we]2928-we hurried into [the barn]589-the barn . [We]2928-we climbed the ladder into [the loft]5240-the loft that was strewn with farming implements and with [carpenters]2941-carpenters ' tools . [We]2928-we sat together on the shavings that littered the bench before the high gable window , and looked out over [the brooks]1476-the brooks and [the woods]600-the woods and [the ponds]2944-the ponds . [The tree - tops]2945-the tree - tops were very near to [us]2928-we , and [we]2928-we felt [ourselves]2928-we the centre of [the waters]1678-the waters and [the woods that spread down [the rainy valley]2948-the rainy valley]2947-the woods that spread down the rainy valley .

" In a few years , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " [we]2928-we shall be [almost strangers]5293-almost strangers . "[0-i]

[He]2949-i looked at [me]0-i with fond , dark eyes and smiled incredulously .

" It is as far , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " to the ' Ram ' as it is for [me]0-i to [London]23-london farther . "[0-i]

" Do n't [you]0-i want [me]2949-i to go [there]1189-there ? "[2949-i] [he]2949-i asked , smiling quietly .

" It 's all as one where [you]0-i go , [you]0-i will travel north , and [I]0-i east , and [Lettie]313-lettie south . [Lettie]313-lettie has departed . In seven weeks [I]0-i go . And [you]0-i ? "[0-i]

" [I]2949-i must be gone before [you]0-i , "[2949-i] [he]2949-i said decisively .

" Do [you]0-i know "[2949-i] and [he]2949-i smiled timidly in confession , " [I]2949-i feel alarmed at the idea of being left alone on a loose end . [I]2949-i must not be the last to leave "[2949-i] [he]2949-i added almost appealingly .

" And [you]2949-i will go to [Meg]114-meg ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

[He]2949-i sat tearing the silken shavings into shreds , and telling [me]0-i in clumsy fragments all [he]2949-i could of [his]2949-i feelings :

" [You]0-i see it 's not so much what [you]0-i call love . [I]2949-i do n't know . [You]0-i see [I]2949-i built on [Lettie]313-lettie , "[2949-i] [he]2949-i looked up at [me]0-i shamefacedly , then continued tearing the shavings " [you]0-i must found [[your]0-i castles]5295-your castles on something , and [I]2949-i founded mine on [Lettie]313-lettie . [You]0-i see , [I]2949-i 'm like plenty of [folks]5225-folks , [I]2949-i have nothing definite to shape [my]2949-i life to . [I]2949-i put brick upon brick , as [they]5225-folks come , and if the whole topples down in the end , it does . But [you]0-i see , [you]0-i and [Lettie]313-lettie have made [me]2949-i conscious , and now [I]2949-i 'm at a dead loss . [I]2949-i have looked to marriage to set [me]2949-i busy on [[my]2949-i house]5297-my house of life , something whole and complete , of which it will supply the design . [I]2949-i must marry or be in [a lost lane]5298-a lost lane . There are [two people [I]2949-i could marry and [Lettie]313-lettie 's gone]5299-two people i could marry and lettie 's gone . [I]2949-i love [Meg]114-meg just as well , as far as love goes . [I]2949-i 'm not sure [I]2949-i do n't feel better pleased at the idea of marrying [her]114-meg . [You]0-i know [I]2949-i should always have been second to [Lettie]313-lettie , and the best part of love is being made much of , being first and foremost in [the whole world]5300-the whole world for [somebody]4142-somebody . And [Meg]114-meg 's easy and lovely . [I]2949-i can have [her]114-meg without trembling , [she]114-meg 's full of soothing and comfort . [I]2949-i can stroke [her]114-meg hair and pet [her]114-meg , and [she]114-meg looks up at [me]2949-i , full of trust and lovingness , and there is no flaw , all restfulness in one another "[2949-i]

Three weeks later , as [I]0-i lay in the August sunshine in a deck - chair on [the lawn]554-the lawn , [I]0-i heard the sound of wheels along [the gravel path]2951-the gravel path . It was [George]313-lettie calling for [me]0-i to accompany [him]313-lettie to [his]313-lettie marriage . [He]313-lettie pulled up the dog - cart near the door and came up the steps to [me]0-i on [the lawn]554-the lawn . [He]313-lettie was dressed as if for [the cattle market]2953-the cattle market , in jacket and breeches and gaiters .

" Well , are [you]0-i ready ? "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said standing smiling down on [me]0-i . [His]313-lettie eyes were dark with excitement , and had that vulnerable look which was so peculiar to [the Saxtons]286-the saxtons in [their]286-the saxtons emotional moments .

" [You]313-lettie are in good time , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " it is but half past nine . "[0-i]

" It would n't do to be late on a day like this , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said gaily , ' see how the sun shines . Come , [you]0-i do n't look as brisk as [a best man]2954-a best man should . [I]0-i thought [you]0-i would have been on tenterhooks of excitement . Get up , get up ! Look here , a bird has given [me]0-i luck " [he]313-lettie showed [me]0-i a white smear on [his]313-lettie shoulder .[0-i]

[I]0-i drew [myself]0-i up lazily .

" All right , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " but [we]2957-we must drink a whisky to establish it . "[0-i]

[He]313-lettie followed [me]0-i out of the fragrant sunshine into [the dark house]2955-the dark house . [The rooms]2956-the rooms were very still and empty , but the cool silence responded at once to the gaiety of [our]2957-we sunwarm entrance . The sweetness of the summer morning hung invisible like glad ghosts of romance through [the shadowy room]2958-the shadowy room . [We]2957-we seemed to feel the sunlight dancing golden in [our]2957-we veins as [we]2957-we filled again the pale liqueur .

" Joy to [you]0-i [I]313-lettie envy [you]0-i to - day . "[313-lettie]

[His]313-lettie teeth were white , and [his]313-lettie eyes stirred like dark liquor as [he]313-lettie smiled .

" Here is [my]313-lettie wedding present ! "[313-lettie]

[I]0-i stood the four large water - colours along the wall before [him]313-lettie . They were drawings among the waters and [the fields of [the mill]635-the mill]2959-the fields of the mill , grey rain and twilight , morning with the sun pouring gold into the mist , and the suspense of a midsummer noon upon [the pond]1010-the pond . All the glamour of [our]2957-we yesterdays came over [him]313-lettie like an intoxicant , and [he]313-lettie quivered with the wonderful beauty of life that was weaving [him]313-lettie into the large magic of the years . [He]313-lettie realised the splendour of the pageant of days which had [him]313-lettie in train .

" It 's been wonderful , [Cyril]113-cyril , all the time , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie said , with surprised joy .

[We]2957-we drove away through the freshness of [the wood]504-the wood , and among the flowing of the sunshine along [the road]738-the road . [The cottages of Greymede]2964-the cottages of greymede filled the shadows with colour of roses , and the sunlight with odour of pinks and the blue of corn flowers and larkspur . [We]2957-we drove briskly up [the long , sleeping hill]2965-the long , sleeping hill , and bowled down [the hollow]2966-the hollow past [the farms]1479-the farms where the hens were walking with the red gold cocks in [the orchard]1040-the orchard , and the ducks like white cloudlets under the aspen trees revelled on [the pond]1010-the pond .

" [I]313-lettie told [her]5077-the mare to be ready any time , "[313-lettie] said [George]313-lettie " but [she]5077-the mare does n't know it 's to - day . [I]313-lettie did n't want [the public - house]5302-the public - house full of the business . "[313-lettie]

[The mare]5077-the mare walked up the sharp little rise on top of which stood the " [Ram Inn]67-ram inn . "[5077-the mare] In the quiet , as the horse slowed to a standstill , [we]2957-we heard the crooning of a song in [the garden]444-the garden . [We]2957-we sat still in the cart , and looked across [the flagged yard]2972-the flagged yard to where the tall madonna lilies rose in clusters out of the alyssome . Beyond the border of flowers was [Meg]114-meg , bending over the gooseberry bushes . [She]114-meg saw [us]2957-we and came swinging down [the path]495-the path , with a bowl of gooseberries poised on [her]114-meg hip . [She]114-meg was dressed in a plain , fresh holland frock , with a white apron . [Her]114-meg black , heavy hair reflected the sunlight , and [her]114-meg ripe face was luxuriant with laughter .

" Well , [I]114-meg never ! "[114-meg] [she]114-meg exclaimed , trying not to show that [she]114-meg guessed [his]2974-you errand . " Fancy [you]2974-you here at this time o ' morning ! "[114-meg]

[Her]114-meg eyes , delightful black eyes like polished jet , untroubled and frank , looked at [us]2957-we as a robin might , with bright questioning . [Her]114-meg eyes were so different from [the Saxton]109-emily 's : darker , but never still and full , never hesitating , dreading a wound , never dilating with hurt or with timid ecstasy .

[They]3001-we were merry together as [he]313-lettie tried on [her]3000-she wedding ring , and [they]3001-we talked softly , [he]313-lettie gentle and coaxing , [she]3000-she rather plaintive . The mare took [her]3000-she own way , and [Meg]114-meg 's hat was disarranged once more by the sweeping elm - boughs . The yellow corn was dipping and flowing in [the fields]955-the fields , like a cloth of gold pegged down at the corners under which the wind was heaving . Sometimes [we]3001-we passed [cottages]3003-cottages where the scarlet lilies rose like bonfires , and the tall larkspur like bright blue leaping smoke . Sometimes [we]3001-we smelled the sunshine on the browning corn , sometimes the fragrance of the shadow of leaves . Occasionally it was the dizzy scent of new haystacks . Then [we]3001-we rocked and jolted over [the rough cobblestones of Cinderhill]3004-the rough cobblestones of cinderhill , and bounded forward again at the foot of [the enormous pit hill]3005-the enormous pit hill , smelling of sulphur , inflamed with slow red fires in the daylight , and crusted with ashes . [We]3001-we reached the top of the rise and saw [the city]3006-the city before [us]3001-we , heaped high and dim upon [the broad range of [the hill]502-the hill]3007-the broad range of the hill . [We]3001-we turned and swung down the slope between [the last sullied cornfields]3013-the last sullied cornfields towards [Basford]70-basford , where [the swollen gasometers stood like toadstools]3014-the swollen gasometers stood like toadstools . As [we]3001-we neared the mouth of [the street]1645-the street , [Meg]114-meg rose excitedly , pulling [George]313-lettie 's arm , crying :

" Oh , look , [the poor little thing]5322-the poor little thing ! "[114-meg]

On [the causeway]3016-the causeway stood [two small boys]3017-two small boys lifting [their]3017-two small boys faces and weeping to the heedless heavens , while before [them]3017-two small boys , upside down , lay [a baby strapped to a shut - up baby - chair]3018-a baby strapped to a shut - up baby - chair . The gim - crack carpet - seated thing had collapsed as [the boys]3019-the boys were dismounting the curb - stone with it . It had fallen backwards , and [they]3019-the boys were unable to right [it]3020-it . There lay [the infant]3021-the infant strapped head downwards to [its]3021-the infant silly cart , in imminent danger of suffocation . [Meg]114-meg leaped out , and dragged [the child]475-the child from the wretched chair . [The two boys]2369-the two boys , drenched with tears , howled on . [Meg]114-meg crouched on [the road]738-the road , [the baby]1267-the baby on [her]114-meg knee , [its]1267-the baby tiny feet dangling against [her]114-meg skirt . [She]114-meg soothed the pitiful tear - wet mite . [She]114-meg hugged [it]1267-the baby to [her]114-meg , and kissed [it]1267-the baby , and hugged [it]1267-the baby , and rocked [it]1267-the baby in an abandonment of pity . [She]114-meg murmured to [it]1267-the baby tenderly , and wiped [its]1267-the baby wet little cheeks with [her]114-meg handkerchief , soothing , kissing , fondling the bewildered mite , smoothing the wet strands of brown hair under the scrap of cotton bonnet , twitching the inevitable baby cape into order . " [Poor little lamb]5327-poor little lamb ! " But [you]798-the boy love [her]4168-a girl do n't [you]798-the boy ? "[114-meg]

" Yes [she]4168-a girl 's [she]4168-a girl 's all right . But [we]3032-we ' ave to mind ' er , "[798-the boy] replied [the boy]798-the boy in great confusion .

" Oh , [poor little lamb]5327-poor little lamb , [poor little lamb]5327-poor little lamb ! "[114-meg] murmured [Meg]114-meg over [the child]475-the child , condemning with bitterness [the boys]3019-the boys and [the whole world of [men]562-men]3038-the whole world of men .

" Wheer 's ' er dummy ? "[3030-one of the boys] asked [one of [the boys]3019-the boys]3030-one of the boys in muffled , self - conscious tones . [The infant]3021-the infant began to cry thinly . [Meg]114-meg released the tiny clasping hand from over [her]114-meg finger , and mounted [the dog cart]3049-the dog cart , saying sternly to [the boys]3019-the boys :

" Mind [you]3019-the boys look after [her]3042-the unfortunate baby well , [poor little baby with [no mother]5332-no mother]5331-poor little baby with no mother . [God]171-god 's watching to see what [you]3019-the boys do to [her]3042-the unfortunate baby so [you]3019-the boys be careful , mind . "[114-meg]

[They]3019-the boys stood very shamefaced . [George]313-lettie clicked to the mare , and as [we]3051-we started threw coppers to [the boys]3019-the boys . While [we]3051-we drove away [I]0-i watched [the little group]3053-the little group diminish down [the road]738-the road .

" It 's such a shame , "[114-meg] [she]114-meg said , and the tears were in [her]114-meg voice , " A sweet little thing like that "[114-meg]

" Ay , "[313-lettie] said [George]313-lettie softly , " there 's all sorts of things in [towns]5333-towns . "[313-lettie]

[Meg]114-meg paid no attention to [him]313-lettie , but sat woman - like thinking of [the forlorn baby]3055-the forlorn baby , and condemning [the hard world]3056-the hard world . [He]313-lettie , full of tenderness and protectiveness towards [her]114-meg , having watched [her]114-meg with softening eyes , felt a little bit rebuffed that [she]114-meg ignored [him]313-lettie , and sat alone in [her]114-meg fierce womanhood . So [he]313-lettie busied [himself]313-lettie with the reins , and [the two]2656-the two sat each alone until [Meg]114-meg was roused by the bustle of [the town]4475-the town . [The mare]5077-the mare sidled past [the electric cars]3060-the electric cars nervously , and jumped when a traction engine came upon [us]3061-we . [Meg]114-meg , rather frightened , clung to [George]313-lettie again . [She]114-meg was very glad when [we]3061-we had passed [the cemetery]3062-the cemetery with [[its]3062-the cemetery white population of tombstones]3063-its white population of tombstones , and drew up in [a quiet street]3064-a quiet street .

But when [we]3061-we had dismounted , and given the horse 's head to a loafer , [she]114-meg became confused and bashful and timid to the last degree . [He]313-lettie took [her]114-meg on [his]313-lettie arm ; [he]313-lettie took the whole charge of [her]114-meg , and laughing , bore [her]114-meg away towards the steps of [the office]4498-the office . [She]114-meg left [herself]114-meg entirely in [his]313-lettie hands ; [she]114-meg was all confusion , so [he]313-lettie took the charge of [her]114-meg .

When , after a short time , [they]3066-they came out , [she]114-meg began to chatter with blushful animation . [He]313-lettie was very quiet , and seemed to be taking [his]313-lettie breath .

" Was n't [he]313-lettie [a funny little man]5334-a funny little man ? Did [I]1267-the baby do it all proper ? [I]1267-the baby did n't know what [I]1267-the baby was doing . [I]1267-the baby 'm sure [they]3066-they were laughing at [me]1267-the baby do [you]5335-you think [they]3066-they were ? Oh , just look at [my]1267-the baby frock what a sight ! What would [they]3066-they think ! "[1267-the baby] [The baby]1267-the baby had slightly soiled the front of [her]1267-the baby dress .

[George]313-lettie drove up [the long hill]3068-the long hill into [the town]4475-the town . As [we]3070-we came down between [the shops]4966-the shops on [Mansfield Road]3072-mansfield road [he]313-lettie recovered [his]313-lettie spirits .

" Where are [we]3070-we going where are [you]313-lettie taking [us]3070-we ? "[114-meg] asked [Meg]114-meg .

" [We]3070-we may as well make a day of it while [we]3070-we are [here]4302-here , "[313-lettie] [he]313-lettie answered , smiling and flicking the mare .
